title: Friday - 9/24/2012
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, I have arrived yesterday for my fall quarter in Dubrovnik. I want to thank my wife, Sue, for letting me go again and holding down the fort while I am gone. She will be coming to visit for two and a half weeks shortly. I look forward to her visit. My son Ed is also planning to come soon. He works for Google and will be in Munich on business so he is coming for a week. It will be good to have him here – two Eds are better than one, i always say. 8-) The flight was great, much better than last year except I had an expected 6 hour layover in Munich. On the plus side I had an aisle seat with no one beside me so it was easy to stretch out and move around. I took the flight with the layover so I could arrive to get some preparation done today for next week. Other flights got me here later. Next week I am offering a “boot camp” for new students. This will help acquaint them with computing and give them the basics of programming. Hopefully it will be fun. TJ, My friend and colleague from last year, is going to be in Zagreb this fall, so I may not see him here. He is offering the same “boot camp” in Zagreb. Dubrovnik is still the bustling place I remember from last year. At the beginning of my stay there are thousands of tourists. I knew that the one millionth person this year was to arrive at the Dubrovnik airport yesterday also. I also knew he or she was on a different airline, so I couldn’t be me. The article is at the following link: http://www.dubrovacki.hr/clanak/41993/i-am-completely-surprised-at-first-i-thought-it-was-a-joke-millionth-passenger I got thinking as I was wandering around today amidst all the tourists, Dubrovnik is a city of about 25,000 people. During the high season about 10 to 16,000 tourists arrive on cruise ships each day, usually staying one day. If a million also have arrived since about May on planes, that is a lot of people. The population must double during the high season. It is much nicer here during the middle of my stay. At the end it is very dead and many establishments are closed. My apartment this year is right in the thick of the activity near the pile (pee-lay) gate of the Old City, but my apartment is remarkably quiet. I miss my old apartment, with the view of the harbor and the thirty minute walk along the Adriatic Sea to work each day. My current apartment does not have the view or the walk. On the plus side I have a three minute walk to work and other nice places to walk. I also have ZERO steps going up to my apartment. I counted them. If you remember, I had 198 steps up to my apartment last year. I am also close to several old churches. I went shopping today to pick up some things I needed in addition to food.The stores close to me here are too crowded and don’t have a good selection. I picked up some essentials last night, but today I decided to walk down to the large Konzum near where I lived last year. I needed a measuring cup, a coffee maker and Vanilla Crunchy Pillows. Those of you who followed last year, you may remember my love affair with Vanilla Crunchy Pillows breakfast cereal. The store near me only had chocolate. I got everything I needed except the coffee maker. The apartment does not have a coffee maker. I thought I would get a French press but the Konzum did not have one. I am going on a dire search tomorrow. I do need coffee in the morning. Fortunately for now, my favorite coffee shop is also three minutes away - Sesame (sez-em). It has been very hot here. Today it was 90 degrees Fahrenheit and hazy and humid. I prefer to think of it as 32 (degrees Celsius) – it seems cooler. After my walk to the Konzum, I decided to stay in for a while and do some school work. It has been so hot here that they have had several wild fires in the hills and agriculture has been suffering. Sound familiar? Last year, I regretted that my camera did not take good low light pictures. So I decided to upgrade to a new camera and I am very pleased with it. The following is a picture I took a little while ago from the Pile gate: [caption id="attachment_637" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Picture of Old City wall from Pile Gate in Dubrovnik[/caption] Well that is all for now. Jet lag is catching up. I think it is time for bed. Hope all is well, Ed

title: Saturday - 8/25/2012 - In search of the coffee press
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: I must not be over my jet lag yet. I went to bed late last night and didn’t wake up until almost noon. That is very unusual for me. So I got up, got ready, which included a breakfast of Crunchy Pillows and went on a search for a coffee press. No success. As I was leaving my apartment, I stopped to talk to Ana, a young girl who stands outside the Mimosa Restaurant drumming up business. Many restaurants here do that. They have a menu and ask if you would like to come in and eat. Mimosa is one of my favorite restaurants here.  I have known Ana since last year. She is very friendly and we tease each other.  Today’s special – either tuna or swordfish for 82 Kuna (about $14). I commented that it was only 80 Kuna on Thursday night. She said I had better eat now because it might be 84 Kuna tomorrow. I will save Minosa for when Sue or Eddie are here. I hope they will still have the fresh Adriatic tuna. I decided to walk to a couple of little malls down near where I used to live and see if there was a coffee press anywhere. They were mostly clothing stores. I tried the Tommy grocery store in one mall but nothing there either. It is pretty hot here so by that time I needed some water, so I bought a large bottle of sparkling water and went to the Promenade to sit a rest a while and drink some water. The Promenade is this long walk down near where I used to live with all kinds of restaurants and entertainment. It ends at the sea with a large beach, which was packed today (88 F). I walked back along the promenade and along the harbor on my way to another little mall and another Tommy. It was a nice walk. Everything seems as it was when I left, except where the promenade hits the main street there is now a roundabout. Two streets used to come to a “T”. The other mall also was mostly clothing stores. The other Tommy had an electric coffee maker, but that is not what I was looking for. So I bought a couple things I needed including a six liter bottle of water (heavy). Fortunately I had my backpack. All-in-all it was a nice walk, but no coffee press. I will have to ask someone on Monday. I know there must be stores that sell that type of thing. Most stores that are not tourist related close early on Saturday and are closed on Sunday, so I may not have found the store open anyway. When I came back to my apartment near the Old City, I decided to do some laundry. And take a short nap. I have a washer and a dryer in this apartment. The dryer is an interesting device. It has no exhaust. I am not sure where the lint goes. There is a little tray on top that fills with water and when it gets full the dryer shuts off until you empty it. I had to empty it three times. It seems to work well, however. After my nap I cooked dinner, chivaps with pasta, peppers, onions, broccoli and tomatoes. Chivaps are small ground meat rolls. As I was eating, I was listening to NPR on my iPad. I called Sue on Skype and we had our usual daily conversation. She is up in the Adirondacks and is expecting a lot of company.  After I cleaned up, I decided to go over to the Old City to find out the Mass times at the Franciscan church. I like that church. They have some beautiful singers. Sue remembered 10:30 and I remembered 11:00. As usual here, there is no sign so I guess I will go at 10:30 and see what happens. This is the music festival in Dubrovnik. Each night there is a concert in from of the Church of St Blaise (Sv. Vlaho). Tonight’s concert is opera with an opera company from Ljubljana, Slovenia and the Slovenian Symphony Orchestra (Somebody tell Dusan. Ljubljana is his home town). It was phenomenal, and I don’t usually care for opera. I could only stay for a few minutes because I was tired and wanted to get home (that jet lag thing again). What I heard was very good. There is nothing like an outdoor concert. I will leave you with a few more pictures. The first is of the concert and the rest are of the wall near the Pile gate at night. Enjoy. [caption id="attachment_643" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Concert at Church of St. Blaise[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_644" align="aligncenter" width="300"] City wall of Dubrovnik near Pile Gate. Way in the background (upper left) is the cross that overlooks the city.[/caption]   [caption id="attachment_645" align="aligncenter" width="300"] City wall of Dubrovnik near Pile Gate[/caption] [caption id="attachment_647" align="aligncenter" width="225"] Inside the Pile Gate[/caption]   Hope all is well. Ed

title: Sunday - 8/26/2012
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a quiet day. I got up this morning at about 8:45, which is good because I had set my alarm for 9:00. Maybe the jet lag is getting better. I enjoyed my bowl of Crunchy Pillows then got ready for church. I wasn’t sure if Mass was at 10:30 or 11 so I arrived at the Franciscan church in the Old City about 10:20. I had forgotten I live only five minutes away. The 9:30 Mass was just finishing which was sung by a great men’s choir (although I couldn’t find the choir).  I used the time to meditate. I have just started reading The Imitation of Christ again, so I had a lot to meditate on. The Mass at 11:00 Mass was beautiful and crowded. There are three girls who sing and do a beautiful job. The closing song is one that we sing at St. Charles a lot, Lord, You Have Come (Pescador de Hombres)? They sing the Croatian version. Here is the English: Lord, You Have Come (Pescador de Hombres)? 1. Lord, you have come to the seashore, neither searching for the rich nor the wise, desiring only that I should follow. Refrain O, Lord, with your eyes set upon me, gently smiling, you have spoken my name; all I longed for I have found by the water, at your side, I will seek other shores. 2. Lord, see my goods, my possessions; in my boat you find no power, no wealth. Will you accept, then, my nets and labor? 3. Lord, take my hands and direct them. Help me spend myself in seeking the lost, returning love for the love you gave me. 4. Lord, as I drift on the waters, be the resting place of my restless heart, my life's companion, my friend and refuge. It is a beautiful song and these girls did a very nice job. It was very meditative. After Mass I walked to Sesame to get a cup of Coffee (stillno coffee maker). So I relaxed a bit under the shade of an umbrella and watched people for a while. A faculty member form ACMT walked by and said hello. I think that is the first ACMT person I have run into. I returned to the apartment and looked at the news to see what is going on in the world. Sorry I looked 8-(.  My daily news habit is to look at BBC, YNN, DemocratandChronicle and Syracuse.com. The last two mostly for obituaries. At almost 62 I am beginning to know more people there. I then worked for the rest of the afternoon except for a couple Skype calls. I thought this would be a good time to work since it is so hot outside. At about 8:30 I decided to take a walk through the Old City, which was still crowded with tourists. I then stopped at the Sandvich shop and got a Chivapcici sandwich. This must be new on their menu. I don’t remember it from last year. It was good. Now I think I will head to bed. Tomorrow I have to move into my office and prepare for the bootcamp for freshmen beginning on Tuesday. I also have to go register with the policija at 10:00. Again, I will leave you with some pictures from my walk tonight. (Note: clicking on the picture will make it full size) Hope all is well. Ed [caption id="attachment_659" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The tower of the Dominican Friary from near the Ploce Gate[/caption] [caption id="attachment_652" align="aligncenter" width="225"] St. Blaise watching over the Ploce Gate[/caption] [caption id="attachment_653" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The top of the church of St. Blaise. Note the windows.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_654" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The dome of the cathedral.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_655" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The busy Stradun (main street) at night. It is still crowded at 9:00PM in the tourist season. At the very far end you can see the tower of the Church at the Franciscan Friary, where i wen this morning.The Pile is just beyond that church and I live just outside the gate.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_656" align="aligncenter" width="225"] A closer view of the tower at the Franciscan church. Note the woman in white in the foreground. She is a human statue. Last year there was a golden man.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_657" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The old harbor from the Ploce Gate.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_658" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Old Harbor from the Ploce Gate[/caption] [caption id="attachment_651" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The wall from the Ploce Gate. Behind the wall, (L to R) you can see the Dubrovnik Cathedral, The Jesuit Church (St. Ignatius) the highest point in the Old City, Church of St. Blaise (dome), and the city bell tower. The old harbor is in the foreground.[/caption]

title: Monday - 8/27/2012 - The great coffee search and other activities
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: This will be a short blog post tonight, as I need to finish preparing for class at 9:00 in the morning. I am doing a boot camp for new students tomorrow and I don’t really know what to expect. It will run from 9:00 until 15:00 with a break for lunch. I also have to have a break every hour because so many students smoke over here. It is a shame to see, actually. I harass them periodically, but it does little good. I woke up to pounding and construction work going on in front of my apartment. My landlord has had a nice grape arbor constructed in front of the building. Tonight he has parked his car under it. I am not sure how that will work when the grapes get ripe and fall on the car. I will let you know. My day started out by moving into my office. It went well, and I got to see a lot of people from last year and it was good to see them. Over the summer one of the faculty members turned my office into a research lab and there is some refrigerator like machine growing protozoa. So they told me that if I start turning green that is a good thing because I am absorbing more carbon dioxide which is good for the environment. Actually, he will be moving it out on Wednesday. I will have two roommates this quarter; one from Rochester (an IT person like me) and another from Zagreb (Philosophy). They should be here at the end of the week for the official start of classes next week. At 10:00 we went to the police to register me as a guest worker. A very simple process as long as it is for 90 days or less. One of our staff has a great relationship with the people there and they don’t even bother to look at my passport. Of course they have a copy and my landlord has already registered me as a resident. We were in and out in 10 minutes. The cab ride took longer. The trick, she says, is to always be honest. Doesn’t that make sense. I then worked with our system administrator to get the lab ready for the boot camp and did some preparation work. After work at about 5:30, I called Sue in the states. She was in Utica at her sister’s and was about to start for Rochester. She had Anna, my granddaughter from Boston, with her and I talked to Anna and her PahBoo (short for Pooh Bear). PahBoo did not say much, but Anna did. Anna is going back to spend the week with Sue.  That will be fun. It will also help Andrea while Ed is on his trip to Munich and his visit to me here. I then went on a mission. 1. Find a coffee maker. 2. Get my phone (borrowed from ACMT) charged up with minutes. 3. Get a 6L jug of water (heavy). I have some but wanted to stock up. If I want a large bottle, I have to go to the big grocery stores. I can get 6L for about 12 kuna. If I buy it near where I live I get a 1.5L bottle for 9 kuna. So it pays to take a walk to the big stores. Success on all counts. The receptionist at ACMT told me of a store that would likely have a coffee maker. It is called Robot and it is near a large Pemo grocery store near where I was on Saturday, next door to the Tommy by the harbor. So close. It seems like no one here has heard of a French press. So I bought a drip coffee maker. It was 199 kuna, about $33; about 33 cents per day. I will “will” it to someone when I leave. It is no good in the USA because it uses different electricity. So I have cleaned it up and it is ready to go for morning. Life is good. I also bought a couple of wine glasses. The apartment only had one. Generally, however, the apartment is well furnished. Also, some interesting news. The HBO series “Game of Thrones” will be filming here again this year, while Sue is here. It was interesting to watch last year although I have never seen the show. I don’t have cable. Here is a link if you want to read about it: http://www.dubrovacki.hr/clanak/42120/game-of-thrones-back-in-september Well that is all for now. I am going to finish some prep work and go to bed. All-in-all it was a good day. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Tuesday - 8/28/2012 - Busy day at boot camp
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: I got up this morning and made coffee. It was so good. The new coffee maker works fine. I had breakfast and got ready for work, including wearing a tie. They expect that faculty will get more dressed up here than in the States. The president and dean walked by my office and commented that he appreciated the tie. He was wearing one too. I had a busy day today. Today was the first day of the IT Freshman Boot Camp. It ran from 9:00 until 15:00 with a break for lunch.  The goal of this three day event is to get the students comfortable with computing. I have 10 new students and of the 10 only one has done any programming. If I contrast that with the US, about 8 would have had some experience in high school. This has its good points and bad points. On the negative side, the inexperienced fear making a mistake so they are somewhat timid and awkward at trying new things.  American students with some experience will usually try anything. On the negative side for American students, they already think they know everything. That presents a different challenge.  Today we discussed basic programming concepts and developed some simple programs using a system called Scratch, developed at MIT. Scratch allows users to “write” programs by just moving things around on the screen so they can concentrate on the basic concepts. Tomorrow we will get more into “real” programming using some graphical tools and a language called Java. It was a nice day here today. The temperature was in the low 80s and is currently about 70F.Everyone is relieved that it has cooled off a bit. On the down side, there is smoke in the air and everyone’s allergies are flaring up. I was talking to Larissa this morning and she said that she had ash on her car the other day. There were two large fires in Bosnia I Herzegovina  (BIH) that have merged into one. It is on the other side of Mt. Srd. It should not be a danger here but there is the smell of burning pine in the air. It has been an extremely dry year here and fires have been common throughout the Balkins. Here is a related article about Serbia and Croatia. This is NOT near me, so don’t worry. http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-19395545 After supper, I decided to walk down to Lapad to do some grocery shopping. I needed some meat, vegetables and fruit.  It was a nice night for a walk. All the big grocery stores are in Lapad. When I got back to my apartment I did a little planning for tomorrow and now it is off to bed. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Americans usually think they know everything. Glad you have coffee :)
The problem with them "knowing" how to program is that you have to have them unlearn some things so you can teach them, the right things. Does that make sense? Anyway, coffee is a good thing.

title: Wednesday - 8/29/2012 - Nothing exciting happened today 8-)
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a very busy but productive day, although there is not much interesting to report. I got up this morning and got ready for day 2 of the boot camp for new students. I always check the weather channel on the Internet to see what the forecast is for the day. It is usually the same – sun and hot. Today I saw a first. The forecast was hot and “smoky”. I never saw that before. This must be what they see all the time out in the western US. Anyway, I took a picture this morning out the 4th floor window of ACMT so you can see the haze in the distance. [caption id="attachment_672" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Old City showing haze from brush fire smoke[/caption] Remember that the 4th floor is actually the 5th floor by US standards. The bottom floor is always called the ground floor. The first floor (our second floor) is above the ground floor. I think it is that way all over Europe. The boot camp went well today. The students seem energized by the material we are covering. The real test will be when the programming course really starts next week. Will they be able to perform better than earlier classes? It will be an interesting experiment. After class tonight, I spent some time rearranging my office so that I don’t have wires running everywhere. I thought I would get it organized before my two office mates arrive later this week. When I finished that I went home to cook dinner and went to one of the local stores to get some milk for cereal in the morning. I also took my garbage to the garbage station. One problem with the stores near me is that they are aimed at tourists, so I can only get smaller, more expensive, sizes of things. I think I have already mentioned this with the water but it is also true for milk. I could only get a 1L size bottle of milk. I prefer the larger one. While I was out, I took this picture of the almost full orange moon over the tower of the Franciscan church from outside the wall near the Pile gate. The moon seems hazy also. [caption id="attachment_673" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Almost full moon over the Franciscan tower[/caption] I wanted to go to daily Mass tonight and thought there was Mass at 19:30 and I heard a bell so I hurried off to the Franciscan church. Oops – Mass was at 19:00. I may try again tomorrow. I would like to get into a daily Mass routine if I can. I came back to the apartment and answered email, organized my calendar and will get ready for bed. A good day, but nothing exciting happened 8-). Hope all is well. Ed

title: Thursday - 8/30/2012 - The last day of the boot camp for new students
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: It has been a good day again. I got up this morning and got ready for work. As I was leaving at about 8:45, my landlord, Niko, knocked at the door to tell me that a painter would be painting my door today. The painter turned out to be his brother so I talked to him for a minute. He had lived in the US for a little while in California with Niko and his wife, but he could not get a green card so he had to leave. He now works on a catamaran that goes among the islands. He works 15 days and has 15 off. He paints during his off days. This assumes I got the conversation right. Niko also invited me to a gathering on Sunday night at 8:00. It is a gathering of English-speaking people in Dubrovnik and somehow a TV crew is involved. It should be fun and I am looking forward to it. I will let you know how it goes. It was nice of him to invite me. I got to school just in time for class. Today I finished the last day of the IT boot camp for new students. I think this went very well. Most of the students seemed to be energized by the experience. I actually had them programming by the second say. I think this will give them a leg up when they start the regular classes next week.  Some of the students have been loading the software on their own computers so they can continue doing things. This was satisfying to me also. After class, I did a couple of cleanup activities in the office then went home. I cooked dinner and cleaned up before going for a walk on some of the waking-only streets behind my apartment. It was an interesting walk. I found that there is a whole maze of walking-only streets behind my place. The door to my landlord’s apartment above me is actually on this street behind me that I can’t even see from my apartment. I am not too familiar with these streets because I have not been in this area before. It was fun to wander around. At 19:00, I went to Mass at the Franciscan church. It was very short and there were probably 40 - 50 people there. There were a lot of nuns. It was nice to be at daily Mass, even in Croatian. They say the rosary and a litany before Mass. I probably should learn some prayers in Croatian. After Mass, I wanted a gelato from Sue’s favorite gelato store, but I decided to wait for her. I spent some time wandering around the Old City. I walked around the old harbor and it was beautiful with an almost full, orange moon. The lights came on and it was even more beautiful. I will leave you with some of the pictures I took tonight. I love this camera. Remember to click on the picture to enlarge it. Hope all is well. The arriving tour buses are the cause.[/caption] That's all for now.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi Ed!  I'm so glad you're blogging again - I am enjoying seeing your gorgeous photos - what type of camera did you end up getting?

Glad you found the coffee maker - I was going to suggest ROBOT but I see you already found it.  There's also a housewares store in the same building, which is where we got many of our things.

Did you end up taking the apartment that Stina and I lived in?  Sounds like it, from the description and the landlord.  Hopefully Luci will bring you some of the dried figs from her family's farm.  They were amazing.  I hope you enjoy the apartment - I know it doesn't have the view of your old one, but the access to the Old City is great for a break in the evening to go wander around and have some sladoled.  :)

There's a Konzum in the Old City near the big market square across from Zagrebacka Banka - it's a little bigger than the tiny one in Pile and I found that if I got there early enough in the day, the selection was pretty good.  They often sell out of meat later in the day.  You're right, though, that you have go go to Lapad or Gruz to get the bigger quantities.  Don't forget there's a small farmer's market in that same square every morning, too, for fresh produce.

I find I'm missing Dubrovnik - please enjoy your time there!  Looking forward to reading more.

Hi Elizabeth,
I decided to upgrade my old Kodak digital camera. I wanted something that would work in low light. I bought a Nikon Coolpix S8200. It is a discontinued model and Rowe had it $80 off, so it put it in the price range of some lesser cameras. I also like the fact that the controls that you use most often are clearly visible and logically placed. I have enjoyed using it, so far. 
I am in your old apartment. I am enjoying it so far but I do miss the view in Lapad. I am finding other places to walk,however. I am not sure if Luci is coming while I am here, but I will look for the figs. One of my students brought me some last year and they are good. 
I have been to both of the Konzums near me. Mike told me about another that is about half way to Gruz, which I will have to find. I have found that it makes a less stressful shopping experience if I walk down to Gruz for any major shopping, and I think the prices are cheaper also. I have not gone to the farmers market yet, but plan to. 
I hope all is well with you and Stina in Rochester. Say hi to Stina. I can believe you miss it here. I think I would too if I were not here. I do love it here. Thanx for reading the blog. Ed
