title: Friday - 8/31/2012 - JMJ(D)
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
JMJ(D)

Today was a busy day. I had a number of things that had to get done before classes officially start on Monday. I decided to work from my apartment and it worked out well. I did have to run over to the office for a little while to upload some large files to our course system. The Internet connection is a little slow for that type of work, though it works well for most other things. After finishing the work I had to finish today I made some dinner. I stir fried some chicken with onions in olive oil with some spice that translates from Croatian to Mediterranean spices. I am not sure what it is, but it is a nice combination. I will have to investigate that. I also made a nice salad with lettuce, tomato, gouda cheese and croutons, drizzled with my favorite balsamic vinaigrette dressing. It was a nice dinner. After cleanup, I went to Mass at the Franciscan church. Every once in a while I recognize a song melody they sing. Last night they ended Mass with “Come Holy Ghost”. Tonight they started Mass with “Michael Row the Boat Ashore”. I chimed in on the Alleluias. All These very serious Franciscan nuns look at me funny. I am going to work harder to learn the Mass responses in Croatian. There is a web site that has sided-by-side translations of the Mass called “The Travelers Mass”. Here it is if you are interested: http://www.angilella.it/missa/ I will be using the en2/hr version. Hr is the official abbreviation for Croatia (Hrvatska). After Mass I walked around the old city for a while. Every restaurant was cooking fish. It smelled so good. I am glad I ate before I came. It was a beautiful evening in the old city. I enjoyed my walk. As I was coming back I noticed that the Dominican church was open. I had never been in there before so I decided to go in and take a look. Last year when I was here it was closed for renovation so I never got inside. Wow, is that a beautiful church! It has a beautiful wood ceiling. I will try to take some pictures some time when the church is open and quiet. I went in and knelt down to say a prayer. There were a few other people in there. After a couple of minutes, a Dominican nun got up and went to close the door. Everyone seemed to take that as closing time. As I walked out I smiled at her and she gave me quite the frown. Not sure what I did wrong. I think the nuns here are sick of tourists who come into the churches more interested in seeing the sights that worshipping the reason for the church. It can be disruptive when services are going on. I have always liked Dominican and Franciscan nuns. When I was in grade school at St. Mary’s School in Fulton, NY, I had Dominican nuns for nine years (K – 8). They were an important part of my upbringing. They always had us put JMJD (Jesus, Mary, Joseph and Dominic) at the top of our papers. When I went to Oswego Catholic High School in Oswego, NY, I continued to write JMJD, but not for long. I was corrected to JMJ since the nuns were Franciscan. I don’t know why it wasn’t JMJF. The Franciscan nuns also played an important part in my life. Now I don’t write anything at the top of my paper. Maybe I should. That would surprise my students. Both of those schools are closed. It is sad to think that few Catholic children today will experience the benefits of a catholic education with the nuns. They certainly kept you going straight. St. Dominic was known as a great preacher. He founded an order of priests called the Order of Preachers (OP) in 1216, followed by nuns in 1218. St Francis founded the Franciscans in 1210. He then founded the Order of Poor Clares with St. Clare. Both orders have a long history. When we got letters from Br. Charles Varnak after he left St. Charles parish and Cardinal Mooney HS in Rochester, he would always write JMJ at the top. It always made you stop and think. He was a Brother of the Holy Cross. The Congregation of Holy Cross or Congregatio a Sancta Cruce (C.S.C.) is a Catholic congregation of priests and brothers founded in 1837 by Blessed Father Basil Anthony-Marie Moreau, CSC, in Le Mans, France. He was beatified in 2007. Sorry for the ramble - one thought led to another. When I got back to my apartment, I had a Skype call with a colleague in Rochester about a course we teach in common. It was good to talk to him. Now off to bed. Tomorrow there is an orientation session at the Imperial Hilton at 10:00, so I will be there. I live next door to the hotel, so I have no excuses. I also have to start thinking about a new picture for the header of this blog. The current one is from my old apartment. I will start looking at my pictures. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Ed, Tell those sisters to smile.  Miriam
I will do that. Actually, I saw a couple of the Franciscan nuns smiling today. So there is hope. Ed

title: Saturday - 9/1/2012 - Birthday? Me?
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Happy birthday to me, Happy birthday to me, Happy birthday dear me, Happy birthday to me. Guess what today is? Yep, it is number 62. All is well here in Dubrovnik. As I was eating breakfast (yes, Crunchy Pillows) I looked at the news and read my email. My first email message was from my buddy John in Oswego wishing me a happy birthday. He turned 62 eight days ago so he is much older than I am. I won't even talk about Sue. I also had an email from Emily. Early in the afternoon here, Laura called me on Skype. So I have had plenty of attention on this highest of days. I also had a couple of cards from Sue and Emily, Zac, Maggie and baby girl that Sue tucked into my luggage before I left along with some chocolate chip cookies. I think I will save the latter for Monday and bring them to ACMT. I have kept them in the refrigerator so I think they should still be good. I also had a nice Skype call from Sue and company at camp in the Adirondacks. They all sang happy birthday, including Anna and Maggie. Anna wanted to know if I could “come over in a minute.” I said it would have to wait. Croatia is a long way away. I also had emails from my good friends Emmett and Janet, and Joyce. It was nice of everyone to remember me on my birthday. I hope I didn’t leave anyone out. I had to get up this morning to go to the beginning of Freshman Orientation at the Imperial Hilton. The opening session was short, less than an hour. It was nice to see all the eager faces. There were short welcoming addresses by the administration and we, the faculty, introduced ourselves.  All my freshman walked in and waved to me. I had them last week in boot camp. I think it will be a good quarter. After the opening addresses, the students headed over to ACMT and Larisa, Doug (a colleague from RIT) and I went to have coffee. We had a nice visit. After an hour or so, Larisa’s husband came to pick her up and Doug and I continued for another hour. Time can fly over a cup of coffee here in Croatia. Doug bought since it was my birthday. For lunch I stopped at a bakery on the way home and bought some burek s mesom ( a pastry with meat) If you want to see what it looked like there is a picture here. It looks like the first picture on the right. http://hr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Burek They also have burek sa sirom (the same pastry with cheese). The pastry is like philo dough. I did some preparation for next week. I then went to the Tommy near Gruz (new harbor) where I used to live. I needed quite a few groceries. They were heavy but it was good exercise. I then came home to make dinner. It was then that the unthinkable happened. I have been saving this bottle of cold pivo (beer) to drink on my birthday. I took it out, found a glass, BUT there was no bottle opener. 8-(  This is a situation I will have to rectify tomorrow. Well, off to bed. Happy Labor Day weekend in the USA. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Happy birthday, Ed.  Mine was Thursday but I am ten years older than you.  Peace, Sister Miriam
Happy birthday to you too, Sr. Miriam. O hope you had a good day. Ed

BELATED HAPPY BIRTHDAY ED. WAS SORRY YOU HAD TO WAIT FOR THAT BEER! ENJOYING YOUR BLOGS> STAY WELL.
PRAYERS, GINNY
Thanks, Ginny. I think the beer was better because I had to wait for it. Ed

Ed:
Happy Birthday "62" on SEPT 1. You have caught me again! Enjoy with many years of good health & good times. Take care and continue to take advantage of a great working opportunity!
Ange
Thank you, Ange. They tell me the first 62 are the hardest. We have all hit the same age now.  Ed

title: Sunday - 9/2/2012 - A bottle opener and a gathering
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: I got up this morning at about 9ish and took it easy until I had to leave for Mass at 11:00. I read the news, answered some email, had breakfast and cleaned up a bit. On my way to the Franciscan church there was a Jazz ensemble just inside the Pile Gate. It was very nice to listen to. Of all times not to have my camera. If they are there again, I may buy one of their CDs. They were very good. Mass was quieter this morning than last week. The singers who I enjoy were not there for some reason. The Mass was still enjoyable. The priest who said the Mass was the one who blessed my plaque to St. Blaise last year. I have a small problem with fruit flies. They seem to have attacked a peach that I have probably had for a day too long. The problem with fruit flies is that they are so small and fast. They seem to disappear when you get near them. The peach has been wrapped and trashed and I hope they have disbursed. I will have to watch my tomatoes, though. One of my emails this morning was from my friend and colleague, Jai, who sent me a birthday e-card with suggestions on what I could do on my birthday, all of which involved – you guessed it – beer. He had read about my misfortune yesterday of not having a bottle opener. The card was very funny. Well, I want to report that my severe problem has been resolved. As you can see in the picture below, I am now the proud owner of a bottle opener. It has a fishing boat on it and says Croatia. I bought it at the souvenir shop across the street for 14.99 kuna (about $2.50). About an hour later that bottle was empty. I don’t know what happened to it. [caption id="attachment_721" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The birthday beer and a bottle opener.[/caption] I spent most of the day preparing for my class tomorrow. I have not taught that class in a while. I also had to run to the office to pick up book I needed. It is a 3 minute commute. I combined that trip with my bottle opener expedition and the purchase of some mayonnaise, which comes in a tube like tooth paste. I better not get those mixed up. I then had a light dinner. I made an egg and olive sandwich. That is when the beer disappeared somehow. Tonight was an interesting evening. My landlord, Niko, who lives upstairs and in California, invited me to a gathering of English-speaking people. Several of them are members of the Dubrovnik Foreign Circle, a group of people living in Dubrovnik from other countries (US, Australia, Canada,...).  They gathered tonight to entertain a film crew who is filming a future PBS special on islands that time forgot. For example – islands with people but without cars. The film crew is staying at the Imperial Hilton and Niko is escorting them around. Tomorrow, they are going to spend some time in Dubrovnik but later they are going to an island off the coast that fits their criteria. I can’t remember the name of the island but it is about an hour from Split. It is only 400 meters from  the mainland and its highest point is only 1 meter above sea level but, it has a hotel and people living there. Look for the special when it come out. I met a lot of very interesting people and it was an enjoyable evening. The film crew was from Chicago. It was nice of Niko to invite me. Well that is all for now. I am off to bed so I am well rested for tomorrow. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Monday - 9/3/2012 - First day of regular classes
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
Today was a very busy day, but good day. I woke up this morning at about 8:00 and I could have slept longer. I stayed up a little too late last night. I had no sooner gotten up than I heard my landlord calling from upstairs. I mentioned to him last night, after the gathering, that the bulb had burned out in the second bedroom ceiling light. I use that room as an office and Ed will be using it this weekend.  I had a bulb, but I couldn’t get the globe off. I was afraid of breaking it. He had an electrician with him and he wanted to change the bulb.

The interesting thing was that they couldn’t get the globe off either. The electrician tried to pry it off and it broke. Oh well, at least I didn’t do it. They put the bulb in and said they would look for a replacement globe. When I came home from work tonight, there was a totally new fixture that looks easier to service.

I got to the office a little after 10 and started printing some things I needed for class. I also looked for online (free) resources for the students to use as reading material. Books are very expensive here. So I am trying to find resources that they can use in place of the text book. I found enough for the first week.

Class went very well. The students seem very enthusiastic. I also found a grader to help with the Java homework grading. She took the course last year and was recommended by TJ. She was happy to be doing anything with programming. She loves it.

I gave out chocolate chip cookies today. Sue sent them in my suit case for my birthday. They were a real hit with my students and a couple of staff members who I saw early in the day. There is one left and I am saving it for our receptionist in the morning. She got the first one today and she can also have the last one.

I had some trouble buying bus passes last week. I could not convince the lady that I lived here. They are very handy to have and cost 150 kuna (about $25) for 20 rides. I like to have them with me for when company comes. One of my friends went and bought them for me today. Last year I had no problem getting them myself. It probably depends on the person at the window.

While on the way to get the tickets I was escorted through a maze of streets that take you almost to the Pile gate but avoids the heavily traveled main street. It was really nice and I think I will use it often. It is less chaotic.

I went back to the office and worked for a little while, getting ready for tomorrow, and then went home. I put some laundry in, made dinner and realized I had forgotten to eat lunch. No wonder I was hungry. After cleaning up, I took out the garbage and went for a nice walk around the old town and harbor. It was a nice walk. I think I am going to turn in early tonight. It has been a busy but productive day.

Hope all is well and happy Labor Day in the USA. Ed

title: Tuesday - 9/4/2012 - My Schedule
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: It was a good and busy day today. I had my second class today. Most are students I know from a class last year. This is my class of juniors. They are a good group of students. Some have wondered what my schedule is like. Under the quarter system at RIT, I teach seven courses per year. In addition to that I am supposed to also provide service to RIT and to the IT community and do scholarship activities, which I do. I had planned on three courses here in Dubrovnik, but I am only teaching two, so I will teach three in the winter in Rochester and two more in the spring. So here is a typical week of my scheduled activities: I usually get up about 8:00 each day. After breakfast I do some work from home, usually course preparation, then go into the office. Monday (a light day) – Class from 14:00 – 16:00 Tuesday – Office hours from 13:00 – 16:00 Class from 16:00 – 18:00 Wednesday (long day) – Office hours from 12:00 – 14:00 Class from 14:00 – 16:00 Class from 18:00 – 20:00 Thursday – Class from 10:00 – 12:00 Office hours from 12:00 – 15:00 Class from 16:00 – 18:00 Friday – Meetings I usually go for a walk in the evening and get to bed between 23:00 – 24:00. Time outside the scheduled activities is spent on scholarship activities or class preparation. Tonight I came home and cooked dinner then went for a walk into the old town. I booked a tour for Saturday for Eddie and I. We will be going to Mostar. Mostar is a city in Bosnia i Herzegovina that is like a Turkish town. It was practically destroyed during the 1991 war but has been rebuilt. Eddie arrives Friday afternoon, if Lufthansa is not on strike. Please pray that they are flying. They have been doing spot strikes and were on strike last Friday. If you want to see some information about Mostar look at the following link" http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mostar That is about all for today. It is 22:35, so I am right on schedule. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: That city looks really interesting!  The picture on Wikipedia of the mosque (at the bottom) almost looks like an image they would have used in one of the newer star wars movies - something on Princess Amedala planet. :-) Have a lot of fun and tell Ed that I say hello! Miss you!
Miss you too. Sounds like you had a good time at camp. Both Eddie and I are looking forward to the trip. I will have some of my own pictures later. Love, Dad

title: Wednesday - 9/5/2012 - Will it rain?
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
It is 10:00 in the morning and I thought I would jot a note about the weather, which has been beautiful since I arrived. Last night on my way home from school, I noticed that it was getting cloudy but then it seemed to clear up. When I got up this morning the Weather Channel app on my iPad had a warning, “Potential disruption due the thunderstorms from 12:01AM CEST to 11:59PM CEST.” That about covers it, with two minutes to spare 8-) . CEST is Central European Summer Time (+6 from the US EDT). The warning went on to say that the chance of lightning was > 60% with potential rainfall > 30mm (about 1.2 inches).

Kevin Williams (10 NBC - Rochester) would have a field day here. The weather is usually the same every day at this time of year – sunny and hot. When rain is predicted it usually doesn’t happen, but when it does, WATCH OUT! The water comes down the hills like crazy. You can be walking uphill in three to four inches of running water. I have only been here once when that happened and it was impossible to stay dry. So we will see what happens today. We really need the rain. Farmers here have had the same type of problems our farmers have – drought.

The sun is out with some clouds but I actually heard a couple rumbles of thunder out to sea. I will report later. This might be a good time to walk over to school so I don’t get wet later.

LATER….

When I walked out of the apartment this morning, there was a fine but sparse mist in the air. I have seen this before. Nothing gets wet; you just feel it as it hits you and evaporates. This may lead to some rain but so far it has not. I stopped at the bakery for some bread in case it rained later and I didn’t want to  stop then.

LATER STILL ….

Well, it is now 23:45 and I have stayed up too late. I have class at 10 AM tomorrow. After my class ended at 20:00 I had agreed to meet one of my colleagues from RIT, Doug, at a hotel at the end of the promenade in Lapad. The hotel has this nice buffet and live ethnic music on Wednesday nights. Doug went last week and I went once last year with TJ and Doug and it was very nice. Guess what, no buffet tonight. Doug asked a waitress and she said it was over for the year – new manager.

I suggested that we go to Restaurant Konavoka about half way down the promenade. So we went there and had dinner. I was there several times last year with TJ and when Sue came. The waitress remembered me. We ordered some wine and I had the chicken Dalmatian style and Doug had stuffed squid. Both meals were excellent. The sauce on my chicken was very good. I have not figured out what the spices are, but they are great. There is a little bottle of “Mediterranean spices” in my kitchen that I love. I have no idea what they are, but they are great. I have to do some research. As we were leaving, it had finally started to rain. But it was like before, not enough to get wet.

It is now 23:53. In six minutes the warning will be over and my goal is to get to bed before midnight. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Hi Ed,

We left those spices there - I really loved that mix, too, and so translated the label.  Mediteranska mješavina (Mediterranean Mix): Rosemary, thyme, savory, basil, tarragon. 

I even wrote about it last year in my blog here:
http://offtodubrovnik.wordpress.com/2011/12/19/these-are-a-few-of-our-favorite-things/

Glad you liked it, too.  :)

Say hi to Doug for me.  I do miss Dubrovnik but I'm enjoying living vicariously through you!

Best,
Elizabeth

Thank you for the spices and the translation. I had not gotten to translate them yet. I noticed that most of your favorite things are mine also (the spice, the orange peals, honey, ajar, civapi and  burek). I make civaps a lot. Great served with peppers and onions and ajar. The ones that are not, I haven't tried yet. Ed

title: Thursday - 9/6/2012 - Rain
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, we didn’t get the thunder or rain that was predicted yesterday in the alert that expired 11:59 PM last night, but by 3:00 AM it was thundering and by 4:00 AM it was raining. They just missed by a little. When I got up this morning the ground was dry and it was sunny, but when I went in for a 10:00 class it was thundering and raining. Lightning struck somewhere and the power went off briefly. One of my students ran into class dripping wet. “I thought I could make it,” he said. As you can see from the picture, it can really rain here. Note the drips from the roof on the top floor. [caption id="attachment_734" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Heavy rains over the Old City[/caption]By late morning it was clear and remained nice for the rest of the day. There is another weather alert today. “Potential disruption due to wind 7PM CEST Thursday until 11:59 PM. Locally strong bora wind with stormy gusts is possible.” The bora (pronounced boorrrah – don’t forget to roll the r.) is a very strong wind that can disrupt many things; air travel for one. Several of my friends have been diverted to Split where they are put on a bus for a four hour ride to Dubrovnik. Hopefully that won’t happen because Eddie arrives tomorrow. So, in keeping with the weather predictions, no wind yet. It was an extremely busy day today. One of my lab classes did not go well. I had a few technical problems. I should have it fixed by next week. I got out of my last class at 18:00 and by the time I got home, had supper, cleaned up and did some laundry, there was not much more time left. I did go to the garbage station and for a short walk through the streets behind my apartment. I had a Skype call from Katie and the boys. Sammy had his first day of preschool. He liked it and the teacher said she thought he would have a good year. Jack can say “papa” very well. That is all for now. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: You mean its not always sunny and blue skies in Croatia? I'm surprised! Miss you, Dad!
It does rain occasionally. The closer you get to winter, the more rain you see. In winter it can rain a lot.

title: Friday - 9/7/2012 - Eddie arrives today
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a good day. I was concerned about a bora (wind) warning this morning, but the receptionist at ACMT told me not to worry because it is always over by noon. It was. So much for the warning until 11:59PM. I had a staff meeting first thing this morning. We do a video conference with both campuses, Dubrovnik and Zagreb. It went well. After the meeting, I worked on a technical problem that disrupted my lab on Thursday. I solved it. It will need a minor change to the configuration of the computers in the lab and the technical support person will do it on Monday morning for me. Good news. I expect class to go more smoothly next week. One problem that I have is that I can’t try out changes on the same configuration we have here before I leave Rochester. We will have to get a test machine in Rochester. After that I spent the afternoon preparing for the arrival of Eddie. Marco, my driver, was going to pick me up at 16:00 to go to the airport. I spied his car and found him having coffee, so we sat together and talked until about 15:50 and left for the airport. Well, the best laid plans,…. We went a short distance and stopped. It turned out there was an accident and traffic was held up about a half hour. Marco called a couple of his friends and found one at the airport who held up a sign with Eddie’s name on it. When he found EdVard, all he said was “wait here for my colleague”.  Eddie waited and we got there quite late. I brought him back to the apartment and got him settled in. The drive from the airport along the sea is beautiful. We then walked around the old city for a while and ate a Taj Mahal (a Bosnian restaurant). Here is a picture. It is a little blurry because I had it set wrong for the waitress and I didn’t want to ask her to do it again. [caption id="attachment_738" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Ed and Ed at dinner at Taj Mahal. Two Eds are better than one.[/caption]We came back home and are going to turn in early. We have a tour group going to Mostar in Bosnia tomorrow morning at 7:50. It should be fun. I may not be able to blog tomorrow. If not, I will catch up on Sunday. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I'm so glad to see that Eddie arrived well and you've posted a photo to prove it! Anna said that "Daddy is being gone too long" today so it's a good thing you're having fun! Two Eds are better than one, we all agree!
Yes, we miss Anna. It won't be long, Daddy will be home. Papa will be a little longer.

title: Sunday - 9/9/2012 - Long walk
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, as promised there was no blog entry yesterday (Saturday).  Eddie and I went on the Mostar trip with a guided tour. It worked out very well. I will catch up with the trip starting at the end of this entry. This morning, Eddie and I slept in a bit and got up after nine.  We had gone to bed late and were tired last night. We decided that we would go for a swim before Mass this morning, so at about 10:00 we went to Donce beach, behind ACMT. We just took a short dip, but it felt great. We then came home to get ready for the 11:00 Mass at the Franciscan church. As we were coming out of Mass an older woman who had been in the church asked me if I spoke English and said her passport and wallet had been stolen and her son was chasing the man who stole it. She asked if I could find the police. Now there are seldom police in the old city but there are usually two standing just outside the gate so I went to get them expecting that they would come and help the woman in some way. Well, I found the police officer in his usual spot. I explained the situation and he said to have her go to the police station and fill out a report, that way if they find it, they can return it to her, but there was nothing he could do now. Interesting response, I thought, correct probably, but interesting. So I started back and then remembered the part about the chase, so I went back and mentioned it and he said, you should have said that first. So he came. So always remember, mention the chase first. Now the whole thing came to an abrupt end, the son was back with his elderly mother, and they had to get the bus back to the cruise ship because it was leaving. The police officer looked mad at me and I just threw up my hands and said “sorry”. This is the first time I have ever seen anything like that happen in Dubrovnik. Remember when traveling; keep your valuables close to your body, even in Dubrovnik, which is noted for its safety. After that, Eddie and I needed gelato for breakfast. I don’t think I have ever had ice cream for breakfast. It was very good, but they were out of my favorite flavor, stacciatella, so I had cookies instead. I may have a new favorite flavor. Sorry, Sue, I couldn’t wait. After that, we decided to tour the west fort, outside the pile gate. I had never gotten to that the last time I was here. It was very nice and offered some nice views of the old city. [caption id="attachment_741" align="aligncenter" width="300"] view of Old Town Dubrovnik from the West Fort[/caption] [caption id="attachment_742" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Lokrum from the West Fort[/caption] We then walked toward my old neighborhood, around the new harbor (Gruz) and had lunch at a little pizza shop at the base on my old street where you can sit on the roof and watch the harbor. Sue, Kelly,  Laura and I ate there when they came last year. It made me miss my old apartment, but I am beginning to like where I am now also. From there we walked the promenade and continued around Babin Kuk (bob-in kook). I always thought that was a funny name. Al-in-in I think we walked for about four or five hours including the stop for lunch. We then walked over to my favorite grocery store, Tommy, and got some groceries including another 6L of drinking water. I got sun burn and my feet hurt but it was a good walk. We took the bus home. When we got home we made some Skype calls and then decided to go to the D’Vino wine bar in the old city. We took a tour of Croatian wines and cheeses. It was fun and good. We then explored around the old city for a while. I saw that the hall of remembrance was open late tonight so we went in. It is a room to remember the 1991 – 95 war and it is very moving. We then came home around 22:00 The wine tour involved these three wines. It was a good / full day. Yesterday’s trip was very interesting. I had bookd the trip when Eddie mentioned that he wanted to see some of the different cultures. The trips with this company have only eight participants, plus the driver/guide. There was a Canadian couple, a Turkish couple, An Irish couple and Eddie and I. We had a good time. The first stop was in Neum, a city in a small strip of Bosnia that separates two pieces of Croatia. It was just a relief stop and Eddie and I had coffee while we waited to leave. There was a nice view from the terrace. We leave Croatia, enter Bosnia, leave Bosnia, enter Croatia then leave Croatia and enter Bosnia on our way. It is a crazy setup. More on the trip tomorrow. Sorry, but it is getting late and I have class tomorrow. Must make Z’s. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Monday - 9/10/2012 - Work day - Part II of trip to Mostar.
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a good day. We got up this morning and went for a swim in the sea at Dance (dahn-chea) beach. We then came home and I got ready for work.  I did some class preparation and went to class. Today was marketing photo day so I had my picture taken and they also came into my class and took pictures as I taught. After class, I did some follow up work and went home to meet Eddie who had been touring all day. We went to tour the Jewish Synagogue which is the second oldest synagogue in Europe (after Prague). They had old Torahs from the fourteenth thru the sixteenth century. I had never been in a Synagogue before. Dubrovnik has had a fairly good relationship with other religions, although there was some repression early in its history. Things were reasonably harmonious until the Nazis appeared in 1941. Eddie had made reservations at a good vegetarian restaurant called …Nishta. The food was very good. I had gazpacho – a very good cold tomato soup and a drink made with orange, apple, carrot and ginger. Both were very good. The main course was an Indian dish.  After dinner we sat and talked with an American couple from Seattle. The tables are very close. We then went for a walk and stopped for a beer along the Stradun. There we met a nice Swedish couple and talked to them for a while. We then returned home. Now for the continuing report on the weekend…. After the stop at Neum, we continued on out journey to a fourth century Roman villa called Mogorjelo. This was a short stop tour the ruins. The ruins were built on top of first century Roman ruins. The villa was destroyed by the Visigoths. It was discovered in the early twentieth century when they were building a nearby rail line and began to dig out some dirt. It is very well preserved. Our tour guide grew up in this area of Bosnia and said that there was a nice museum here when it was Yugoslavia. Unfortunately it was destroyed during the war and the artifacts have been moved to another location. [caption id="attachment_756" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins cooking area[/caption] [caption id="attachment_755" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins sleeping quarters for the family. Note the opening under the floor. This was flooded with hot water to keep the family warm during cold months. Fourth century radiant heating.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_754" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins[/caption] [caption id="attachment_753" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins[/caption] [caption id="attachment_752" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins[/caption] [caption id="attachment_751" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins[/caption] [caption id="attachment_750" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Roman ruins[/caption] [caption id="attachment_749" align="aligncenter" width="300"] An olive press at the Roman ruins[/caption] After that, we went to the Kravice waterfall. This was an unauthorized stop, so don’t tell the boss. Our guide knew of a couple of other places that he thought we might like to see and if we would take some time away from a couple of other stops we could stop at these sights. The waterfall was very pretty and was actively used by people in the area as a swimming hole. The falls was pretty and was somewhat unique. I have not seen the falls with an overgrowth in the US. I have seen them several times here. Pictures will describe it better than I can. The only problem here was that we lost Eddie. You have to keep an eye on those kids (37 years old). Our guide was able to find him. [caption id="attachment_761" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Eddie and I at the waterfalls[/caption] [caption id="attachment_762" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Waterfall[/caption] [caption id="attachment_758" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Waterfalls[/caption] [caption id="attachment_759" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Interesting stone roof[/caption] [caption id="attachment_760" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Top of the waterfalls[/caption] Our next stop was a quick stop near Medugore at the Herceg Ecological Village. It was interesting as a model village set up demonstrate different farming activities. We were only here about 15 minutes. They did have a very friendly miniature horse. [caption id="attachment_766" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The sign for the Eco Villiage[/caption] [caption id="attachment_765" align="aligncenter" width="225"] A very friendly miniature horse[/caption] [caption id="attachment_764" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The farm yard at the Eco Villiage[/caption] We then arrived at Medugore. This was intended to be only a one hour stop. That is why I decided against it last year. There is not really time to do anything that pilgrims consider important, like climb the hill, but this trip was really about going to Mostar. It was nice to stop here. Mass was going on in English and wherever you walked you could hear it. The Canadian couple was interested in the statue of the resurrected Jesus with the knee that is constantly wet, for no apparent reason. So I took them there so they could witness the miracle. It was also nice to be at Medugore on the feast of the Nativity of the BVM (8 September). I would like t have had more time there, but I plan on returning with Sue when she comes. [caption id="attachment_763" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Eddie and I at Medugore[/caption] We then left Medugore for Mostar and I will report on that in my next post. Hope all is well, Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Looks like you're having a good trip so far! Those waterfalls look beautiful! Miss you!
Yes, they were beautiful. We enjoyed the total trip. Miss you too.

title: Tuesday - 9/11/2012 - The honors dinner and Part III of the weekend trip to Mostar
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was another good day. They had predicted rain but it did not occur. When we got up, we decided to do some touring. We went to one museum that was closed on Tuesdays so we will try again tomorrow. So we went to have an early lunch since we had skipped breakfast. We stopped at the pizza restaurant Olivia. We then went to tour a couple of churches. We started with the Dubrovnik Cathedral. It is a beautiful church. In the front behind the alter there is, what is called, “the treasury”, but it contains relics. I had not seen this before when I was here. As Eddie said, you might expect that the way into the treasury was through the area that said exit – a little confusing. In the treasury, there were several relics of St Blaise, his arm, his head and his leg. There was a relic of the true cross.  And many others including a “casket” made of silver by a Dubrovnik silver smith that legend says contains the diaper of the baby Jesus. I am not sure I believe that one, and they do say it is legend. We then went and toured the church of St. Blaise. That is a beautiful church also. After that we headed home. I had to get ready for work and Eddie was going sea kayaking and snorkeling. I worked until 18:30 then had a break until 20:00 so we caught up on each others' days. Then I had to attend the honors dinner across the street at Mimosa restaurant. It is always enjoyable to see the students with high averages. In order to qualify, students had to achieve a 3.4 average or above. It was a good evening – good company and good food. When I got home I found Eddie reading and with sore arms from the paddling earlier in the day. PART III of our trip to Mostar I will continue the story of our Saturday trip to Mostar.  After all of our stops we finally ended up in Mostar. Mostar is a city in Bosnia that is occupied by both Croats (Catholic) and Bosniaks (Muslim). This is a place that you see the other side of the 1991 - 1995 war. In Dubrovnik, you see the Croatian side where the Serbs attacked mercilessly. In Mostar you see where the Croats attacked. Some of the damage has not been repaired. Part of the reason seems to be lack of money and part seems to be that they want the reminders.  Bombed out buildings sit in the midst of other buildings. The greatest symbol of the destruction is the famous bridge that was destroyed by the Croats. To demonstrate that hostility still exists, our guide (a Croat) said to notice that the last bomb to destroy the bridge came from underneath. In other words, the Bosniaks destroyed the bride themselves. I didn’t see that in the video, they all seemed to come from above. We had some time here. We stopped for dinner in the bazaar and enjoyed the food. We shared a table with the Canadian and Irish couples. We also had time to wander. We were warned to be careful of beggars and pick pockets. Here are a few pictures from Mostar (click to enlarge photos). If you want to read about Mostar here is a Wikipedia link. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mostar [caption id="attachment_776" align="aligncenter" width="300"] A bombed out building that has never been repaired.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_777" align="aligncenter" width="225"] A map of Mostar. Croats on one side, Bosniaks on the other.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_778" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Vendors in front of bombed out buildings.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_779" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Bombed out buildings in the middle of a block of useful buildings.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_780" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The famous bridge from the Croat side[/caption] [caption id="attachment_781" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The river and swimmers[/caption] [caption id="attachment_782" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Muslim side.Note the ancient Mosque.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_783" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The Muslim side of the river[/caption] [caption id="attachment_784" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Patterns in the pavement were everywhere[/caption] [caption id="attachment_785" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The bridge from the Muslim side[/caption] [caption id="attachment_786" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The river[/caption] [caption id="attachment_787" align="aligncenter" width="225"] A museum and shop on the Muslim side of the bridge. Note the pictures on the sign show the bridge gone before reconstruction.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_788" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Original license plates for sale in the Bazaar. Do you notice that one looks unusual?[/caption] [caption id="attachment_789" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The bazaar[/caption] [caption id="attachment_790" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Eddie and I with the bridge in the background[/caption] [caption id="attachment_791" align="aligncenter" width="225"] Good buildings and bad.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_792" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Well near the Mosque[/caption] [caption id="attachment_793" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The river and bridge[/caption] [caption id="attachment_794" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The minaret at the Mosque[/caption] [caption id="attachment_795" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Dolls for sale[/caption] [caption id="attachment_796" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Copper smiths made interesting patterns.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_797" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Here is why it continues.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_798" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Items for sale in the bazaar[/caption] [caption id="attachment_799" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Hookas for all.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_773" align="aligncenter" width="300"] War memorabilia for sale[/caption] [caption id="attachment_774" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The surface of the Mostar bridge. Notice that the top is the original, worn version the bottom is the new reconstruction. This is a World Heritage Site and it was rebuilt using the same techniques as the original.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_775" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Be careful[/caption] I will post a bit about our final stop at Pocitelji tomorrow. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Wednesday - 9/12/2012 - Typical day - Part IV of weekend trip
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a very busy day for me. When we got up, Eddie and I decided we would go to the museum that was closed yesterday. It was the Rupe Granary and the Ethnographic Museum. Here is a link to a site about the museum. http://www.galenfrysinger.com/croatia_dubrovnik_museum.htm It was very interesting.The granary was build to store grain for the population of Dubrovnik. They had a two year supply. Large containers were carved into the solid rock to provide cool, dry conditions best suited for storage of grain. The upper floors are dedicated to Croatian culture and there was part of a special exhibit dedicated to St. Blaise and the annual celebration. The part is in the rector's palace. After that we went home and I got ready for work then Eddie and I went to have coffee at Sesame before class. I had class and office hours today and my last class ended at 20:00. While I was working Eddie went to Lokrum Island and had a good time there, including swimming. When I got home, we had dinner at Domino steak house, my favorite restaurant in Dubrovnik. I had Steak Ragusa which is smothered in sauteed onions and has grilled vegetables. We had a very good Croatian red wine and sparkling water. We were there for a couple of hours and really enjoyed ourselves. One of my friends from ACMT works there as a host and we had a nice conversation with him also. Now back home and to bed. I have an early class tomorrow. Part IV of the trip Now the final installment of out trip to Mostar. On the way home from Mostar we stopped at Pocitelji. I had stopped there last year after my trip to Medugore. It is an interesting Muslim town in the midst of Croat territory in Bosnia. Here are some pictures of this stop and a link from Wikipedia about the town. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Po%C4%8Ditelj [caption id="attachment_809" align="aligncenter" width="225"] This tree is 500 years old and stands in front of the Mosque in Pocitelji[/caption] [caption id="attachment_810" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The tower on the wall in Pocitelji[/caption] [caption id="attachment_811" align="aligncenter" width="300"] War destruction happened here also[/caption] [caption id="attachment_803" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The town showing the Mosque[/caption] [caption id="attachment_804" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The view in one direction. This point commands the entire area.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_805" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Eddie and I in front of the tower overlooking the city[/caption] [caption id="attachment_806" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Ruins of the building in front of the tower[/caption] [caption id="attachment_807" align="aligncenter" width="300"] View from the entrance to the building at the base of the tower[/caption] [caption id="attachment_808" align="aligncenter" width="225"] Eddie coming out of the tower. Our guide advised not climbing the tower because the stairs are narrow. I had gone up last year and Eddie did this year.[/caption] When we left Pocitelji our guide drove through his old neighborhood and showed us the small house he grew up in and it gave him an opportunity to wave to his family and friends outside. When we got home on Saturday evening, I mentioned that we were going to get pizza and our guide sent us to Tobasco Pizza. It was very good and I think I have a new favorite pizza place. That completes the report on hour trip to Mostar. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Who was the guide?
I will send an email with the information. Ed

title: Thursday - 9/13/2012 - Busy, stormy day
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
This will be a short post. We have a driver picking us up at 5:30 to take Eddie to the airport. He has enjoyed himself but he will be happy to see his family in Boston.

Today Dubrovnik lived up to it weather forecast. We had wind and rain and thunder off and on all day. I went to work early for a 10:00 class, then office hours and another class from h16:00 until 18:00. Eddie decided to climb Mt. Srd and then tour some museums he had not seen yet. It definitely was not a swimming day due to the high waves which can be dangerous. We met back at the apartment at about 18:30 and go ready for dinner.

We were going to Ragusa II, one of my favorites. We were meeting my colleagues Doug and Paul and Paul's girlfriend, Sanja. We had an interesting night of conversation over some good food and wine. It was very enjoyable.

Eddie walked up Mt Srd with a plan of taking the cable car down, but the cable car stopped running because of the wind. When he inquired about when it might run again he was told maybe an hour or tomorrow. He walked down. It is a nice walk. There is a Napoleonic fort at the top and it was used during the 1991 war to defend the city. There is a war museum at the top. It was very moving.

Last night I forgot to mention that when we finished dinner we walked by a restaurant that had jazz playing. The group of three men was very good. As we arrived, the singer started to sing Louis Armstrong's "It's a wonderful world". He had a voice like Louis' and it stopped traffic. Everyone seemed to stop to listen. It was very good. That is one of my favorite songs. There is a version of it that I heard once where Louis talks in the middle. I have never been able to find that version.

Well that is all I have for tonight. Time for bed.

Hope all is well. Ed

title: Friday - 9/14/2012 - Eddie left, stormy day
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, I got up at 4:30 this morning. As I was telling someone later, I didn’t even know there was a 4:30. 8-) .  Anyway, I had to take Eddie to the airport. Marco, our driver, was here at 5:30. I hated to see Eddie leave. We had a good time this week and it was fun having him here. I think he had a good time also. When we got to the airport, the three of us had coffee and then we walked him to the gate. He had to get home in time to see the Arlington (MA) Day fireworks. He was also missing Andrea, Anna and Lucy. He has been away for three weeks, two in Munich for work and one here. Oh well, I hope he passes this way again. It was nice to have some together time. On the way back from the airport, I arranged to have Marco pick me up on Sunday at 11:00 to go to get Sue. She comes in at 11:45. I am looking forward to seeing her. She will be staying with me for about two and a half weeks. When I got home I decided to rest for a while. I had no particular time I had to be in today. My only scheduled appointment was a 14:00 Skype call with my department chair back in Rochester. I used the time at home to catch up on laundry. I washed a white t-shirt with a yellow bed spread. Don’t do that. I am not sure how I will get the color out of the shirt. The weather today was not predicted to be good. There was a 70% chance of rain and we got it along with wind, thunder and lightning. When it rains here the lights flicker and even go out occasionally. It also cooled down, it is now (21:00) 18 degrees (66F) and it feels good. Everyone here is wearing jackets and I am still in shorts and a short-sleeve shirt. There were four alerts today on the weather channel app: Potential disruption due to wind until Fri, 11:59 PM Potential disruption due to rain until Fri, 11:59 PM Potential disruption due to wind until Fri, 11:59 PM Potential disruption due to rain until Fri, 11:59 PM The last two look pretty much like the first two. It must mean they are serious about it. They were right. I went into the office about noon and worked on a couple technical problems. I have one I don’t see to be able to solve. It will be there for another day. I got home just before 17:00 and decided to get some groceries, but by the time I got ready it was raining again so I decided to get dinner. I had a nice dinner and decided to go to Mass at 19:00. Today is the feast of The Exultation of the Cross and the priest wore red. It reminded me that I saw a relic of the true cross in the cathedral treasury, the other day. It made it special. After Mass I started to leave the old city and turned around to get a gelato at my favorite place. I was wearing an RIT shirt tonight. When the worker filled my cone, he saw the RIT and asked if I was at ACMT. “Yes,” I said. “Faculty?” “Yes,” I said. “Do you teach American students?” “No, I teach Croatian students.” “I have never seen you before.” “I came last year, I am here from August through November, just the Fall quarter.” “No charge.” We spoke for a couple minutes. I thought that was very nice of him not to charge me.I had heard that that store gave a discount to ACMT faculty, 7kn instead of 10kn, but I have never asked for it. Well that is all for now. I thought I would leave you with a couple weather pictures.  Remember to click on the picture to enlarge it. Hope all is well. Ed [caption id="attachment_840" align="aligncenter" width="300"] A picture of the entrance to the old harbor taken yesterday by Eddie yesterday[/caption] [caption id="attachment_841" align="aligncenter" width="300"] A picture of the entrance to the old harbor taken yesterday by Eddie yesterday[/caption] [caption id="attachment_842" align="aligncenter" width="300"] A picture of the entrance to the old harbor taken yesterday by Eddie yesterday[/caption] [caption id="attachment_839" align="aligncenter" width="300"] This is a bay visible from the city wall. Rough seas.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_837" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Note the clouds over the Stradun when I came out of church. They would glow when the lightning flashed.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_838" align="aligncenter" width="300"] This is a small harbor on the outside side of the old city across from where i live. Note the waves and all the boats are out of the water. There is a restaurant on the right that has put up a plastic barrier to protect the customers.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_836" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Although from a different angle, this is the same harbor last week in nice weather.[/caption]

title: Saturday - 9/15/2012 - Quiet day, let's make some croutons
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
Well, it was a quiet day today, which was good. I had been out every night with Eddie and I think it caught up with the old man. I slept until about 10:00 this morning, which is unusual for me.

I got up this morning and decided to give the apartment a good cleaning. I swept all the way through, shook the rugs, cleaned the sinks, toilet and shower and generally straightened up. The apartment looks pretty good.  Did I mention Sue was coming tomorrow?

After I finished cleaning the apartment, I did some school work for a while. The work involved things here and in Rochester. We are going through our accreditation review in Rochester and there was a need for more information, which I provided.

After school work, I boiled some eggs for a sandwich later and then I went to get groceries. The store I like is about a 30 minute walk from my new apartment. It is down by the harbor where I used to live. It is a nice walk. One of the things I needed was some water which I like to buy in a 6L bottle (about 1.6 gallons). This is heavy. I brought my backpack to carry the heaviest things. Well, I bought too many things, so I took the bus home. On the bus I ran into one of my colleagues, Doug who had been down on the promenade for the afternoon.

When I got home. I made egg and olive for my sandwich and also made some croutons for salads or soup. I can't eat a whole loaf of bread so I always have a stale piece around that I keep for this purpose. I started making croutons last year. The don't sell anything like that here but they are easy to make.

What is funny about this is that I had forgotten that I knew how to make croutons. Last year I mentioned to Sue when she was here in Dubrovnik that I wished I had croutons.  So she made some. It was like this watershed of knowledge fell over me and brought me back to my youth in Fulton, NY. That was before you could buy croutons in the store, you know, back in the stone age (1950's). My Aunt Hazel lived next door to Moon's bakery on Oneida Street and she would always have some of their good bread left over. Aunt Hazel was a fantastic cook and often would let me cook with her. She taught me how to make croutons, among other things. Seeing Sue make these brought all this back, So, I continue to make croutons over here.

Croutons are easy to make and there is no one recipe. Experiment a little. The basic recipe is a follows: Cube the bread and fry the cubes in a little butter. You had better write that down 8-) . The variation I use here is to use olive oil and butter, add some crushed garlic and those Mediterranean spices I mentioned in an earlier post. So when Sue arrives tomorrow she can have a salad with croutons. It has been too warm to make soup, but soon.

Sue left today from Rochester. The Jet Blue flight was an hour and a half late.There was a problem with the plane and they had to send another. When I saw that the plane had left, I went over to Mass at the Franciscan church followed by a little walk. When I got back I called her at JFK and we talked for a while. She was at the Aer Lingus gate from where her next flight was leaving and she was looking for food.  She has some time before the next flight.

I am a little worried tomorrow because we have one of those weather alerts: Potential disruption due to wind in effect from 12:01 AM CEST SUN until 2PM CEST SUN. maximum-gust-speed>65 km h; Strong bora wind with stormy gusts. Sue's plane is scheduled to arrive at 11:45. The bora can close the airport and the planes divert to Split which is a four hour bus ride away. Let's hope that does not happen. The bora usually ends before noon.

Well, off to bed now.

Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Fingers crossed for Sue!  I've been on that 4-hour bus ride from Split and it's no fun at all.  Seems like the bora has made an early appearance this fall.  Last year we had only one incident in October and then it really didn't start up until November!
The wind and rain have been a little early this year. Fortunately the bora ended before noon, but the flight was very bumpy and had a hard landing. But she got here OK. Thanx for the crossed fingers.

title: Sunday - 9/16/2012 - Sue is here
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: I made it!! Most everything went smoothly, although the landing here in Dubrovnik  today was rough. Aside from being very tired--hard to sleep when you're that crowded--it was OK. I went from Rochester to JFK, to Dublin, then Croatia. It was about 18 travel hours, but several were layover time. The flight to JFK was so smooth that about 40 minutes into the 50 minute flight, a lady 80+ yrs old, next to me, said,  "Do you know what the hold-up is?  I can't figure out why we haven't moved yet."  She was so relieved when I told her we were flying and almost there. Ed and driver, Marco met me about noon today and we drove the 1/2 hour to his apartment. I was a little nauseous from the landing and the winding roads so I immediately laid down and slept two hours. When I got up, I felt a lot better and we went for a swim-- just a 5 min walk away, near Ed's campus. The weather here is back to a sunny, breezy, 80 degrees, so it felt good and helped me wake up.  Just have to remember not to talk when I'm facing TOWARDS the high waves. Mouth full of salt water! We went to that Domino's Steak House for a great dinner.  It's in the old walled town and you can eat outside. Wonderful steak with a mushroom sauce and baked potato "in tin foil".  That's actually what the menu said,instead of mentioning the whipped sour cream, garlic, and chive topping?? After dinner, we went to Mass at the Franciscan chapel, which is always beautiful, although  have to admit, I was fading a little from fatigue. I normally try to get something out of every homily, believing something was meant for me to hear.  Maybe it takes longer when it's all in Croatian.  I did recognize Kum-Ba Ya and Come Holy Ghost. Conveniently, the Franciscans built their 1600's chapel across from a gelato shop.  We just ended our day there and I'm going to sleep early! [caption id="attachment_852" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Sue getting ready to write tonight's blog post.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Ha ha!  Those Franciscans sure had a lot of forethought, didn't they?  

Glad you made it safely!  Enjoy your visit!

I was thinking about you traveling and keeping you in my prayers.  So glad you got there and I finally am able to read the blog since I am back in CT.  Did not know the website name.  Ed was tired when he got home and rested awhile before the girls got home.   Looking forward to reading the blog.
Glad you made  . Enjoy. Sister Miriam

SUE: Glad to hear you had a safe trip. Enjoy your time in Dubrovnik with ED!

title: Monday - 9/17/2012 - Sue's first full day
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: This is not too hard a place (or lifestyle) to get used to again. Ed woke me up at 9:30 am, after 12 hours of sleep!, so I would get myself off jet lag and on a Croatian schedule. I'm still awake, so I guess it worked.  I do have to admit that at 3:30 this afternoon, I had to "re-start" my day with a pot of coffee. We took a walk, before Ed went to work, from one gate of the Old Town to the other and around the harbor. I then walked over to the college with him to bring the chocolate chip cookies I had baked for his staff and students. They're quite the hit here--apparently hard to find, in spite of all the bakeries. I went back to the apartment to unpack and "make myself at home." I dampened a few pieces of clothing that had gotten very wrinkled and hung them on the clothesline to dry, swept our little patio area, and enjoyed my afternoon coffee with my novel, "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn" (thanks, Andrea). Somehow neither one of us read it in HS. It was too nice a day not to get a swim in, so I went back to the Old Town hoping to remember how to get to the door in "the wall"  leading to one of my favorite swim spots. I found it right away and, even though it was crowded with much younger people than myself, I went in anyway. I was encouraged by the "diving lady". Kelly and Laura will remember her and I will tell the story another night. Ed and I made dinner together at the apartment tonight and then made plans for a weekend trip to Plitvice Lakes National Park. This coming weekend seemed to be all booked up, so we plan to go on Sept 28-30th. We got in another walk around Old Town tonight also, including the gelato shop. Lots of live music around every corner and the streets were as busy as in daylight. So that's been my day--walks, swimming, reading, eating, more walks, gelato--it's a rough life, but somebody's got to live it... title: Tuesday - 9/18/2012 - A Cloud on the Horizon
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, I'm not going to make the mistake I made yesterday. Restarting my day with a pot of coffee at 3:30 pm! It did keep me awake---I was still awake at 11:30pm, at 12:30am ...so today I had my last cup at noon and I'll see how this works. Yes, there is A cloud in the sky. That probably means we may get rain some time in the next week. I 'll keep everyone posted. This am, before Ed went to work, we decided to take a walk up behind his apartment to see where the trail to Mt. Srd starts. We wouldn't have time for the hike up the mountain today, but hope to climb it this weekend. It was a perfect 72 degrees when we awoke, but by the time we went, it had to be 80+ in the sun. Just to get to the trail, I counted 468 stairs! That's not even counting a lot of walking on inclined stoned walkways, where they didn't build stairs. SO, I told Ed that it will have to be much cooler and cloudier before I could make the climb up the mountain. I'm used to hiking in the Adirondacks, but the trails are in shady woods. I got a late afternoon swim in again behind Ed's campus. Tried to mail a couple of postcards, but the PO closed at 3 pm. I probably won't mail as many this year, as this blog keeps us in contact. We're planning on dinner tonight at a place near the Ploce Gate that we spotted last year, but never tried. You sit outdoors, under a beautiful, huge tree, overlooking the harbor. 3 hours later...We just returned from a wonderful dinner at that restaurant, Revelin Klub,it's called. We both had turkey gorgonzola with roasted potatoes, peppers, zucchini and onions. The views were amazing, as you'll see in the photos that we'll add. title: Wednesday, 9/19/2012 Revisited Lapad
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
This was Ed's long day at work, so I decided to take an afternoon trip back to the Lapad Peninsula where his apartment was last fall.  Ed loaned me his bus pass to use to get to that area, as I wanted to save my walking for a trip around the peninsula. Bathing suit under the clothes today; I plan to hit some beaches.

I set out around noon and didn't get back to the apartment until after 5pm. I got off the bus this am at "the Promenade" on Lapad. I felt a little nostalgic for the old apartment when I went by the foot of the hill where it's located, and for the whole area, as the bus passed "Ed's harbor." I headed down the familiar promenade, past that area's favorite gelato shop (that would wait til later). 

My first stop was the Lapad Beach, the very first beach I swam at last year.  This time, however, I did not make the mistake of sitting on a $6 chair with a $6 umbrella. I set towel and backpack up along a break wall and got my water shoes out--my best investment from last year. Today's beaches were going to be "walk-in" ones, and the bottom is very small pebbles or coarse sand.

The water is a little cool, but not at all hard to get into.  I swam a short time, dried off, then began my trek along the shaded path,  with the beautiful sea and pine trees to my left. I decided that I had lots of time, so I stopped at the outdoor eating area for Hotel More, and had a delicious Greek salad.

My next stop was the small swimming area at the end of the peninsula.  No name, but local people seem to know it's there and it's a jewel!  Blue-green water with a white rock bottom and wonderful mountain views. Again, I swam for a while, dried off and headed for Cava Beach, which is on the side of the peninsula,headed back.  I asked about kayak rentals, which were under $7/hr. Unfortunately, there wasn't an hour left before they closed, so they told me to come back another day. I wish that I had told them I'd pay the money and just kayak for whatever time was left. I still think it was good deal and the waters were very calm here compared to around Old Town where Eddie went last week. Oh well, I did get a nice swim in here.

I walked past Copacabana Beach (I could practically hear Barry Manilow singing). Not the kind of beach where I like to swim --way too busy. Somewhere after this I took the high road, when I should have taken the low road, close to the harbor. I ended up walking through a RV and tent campground, that I knew I shouldn't be seeing and the harbor was farther away.  Occasionally, I could look down and see the path I should have been on, but the only way to get to it was by climbing tall fences. I didn't want headlines in local papers to read :"Middle-aged American Woman Arrested on Private Property Near Harbor!" So I continued on my not-so-scenic road, at least being able to tell I was headed in the right direction.

I eventually worked my way to familiar territory-the promenade, with it's gelato stand. I enjoyed a small scoop of strawberry, then headed to the grocery store.  I bought way to many things for the bus trip home. Besides stuffing my backpack, I was carrying a LARGE container of water and an even bigger bag of toilet paper.  I was not a comfortable sight on the bus, having to stand much of the trip.

Anyway, I made it back and Ed is due home shortly.  We're going out for pizza! Same place Eddie went with Ed last week--Tabasco--4 cheese pizza, delicious.
I promise a shorter blog tomorrow. The rain should keep me quiet.

title: Thursday - 9/20/2012 - Quiet day, dinner with friends
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, yesterday may have sounded like an adventurous day with my walk around the peninsula, but that was nothing compared to the dangerous thing I did today. I colored my hair from a package of Croatian hair color, not being positive what the color or instructions said. I should have done this before my trip, but ran out of time. Anyway, I sat around this AM worried that I might be turning some weird shade of purple, or greenish! or some off shade of red, "that nature never intended" (in Ed's aunt's words). But I think it came OK.  While it was drying, I sat on the upper part of our patio, where we have an interesting "fake water view".  It's actually a large screen, with a mirror in the middle. On the screen are continuous water scenes, some very blue, some golden or red at sunset. Sadly, these scenes are alternated with bombing scenes from the '91 war (lest we forget!)   We can actually see a little real water to the side of the screen. Ed stopped back at the apt. during his break and we warmed up a slice of last night's pizza for lunch. That's a nice thing about him living so close this year-he can stop home easily. When he went back to work, I walked up to the park behind his building and read.  No swimming today--it cooled off dramatically after an overnight rain. Tonight we met a colleague of Ed's from work at a restaurant on the Lapad peninsula.  We took a bus down and back. We had a wonderful time with his friend, Paul, and his girlfriend, Sanja. It was their first time at the restaurant, but we had been their before.  We were happy this time to have indoor seating with the cool evening.  Ed had a grilled tuna steak and I had chicken, both cooked "Dalmation-style", which a friend pointed out last year must mean "with lots of garlic!"  Anyway, great company and great food. title: Friday - 9/21/2012 - Small fish fried and sunset on Mt. Srd
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a day with no classes for Ed, although he did have a couple of meetings.  They weren't until 11 am and 12 noon, so we took care of a couple of things first.  First, we stopped at the Hilton Imperial Hotel to rent a car for tomorrow.  We plan to make a trip to Medjugorje. Then, I mailed a couple of postcards and we even had time to sit outside at a cafe for coffee. Everything was within a couple of blocks. Liking this location more & more. Last night, Ed's friends mentioned a good place for a fish dinner and I had my mouth watering for that when Ed got home from his meetings. We placed a couple of phone calls before we set out to the "fish" restaurant at the harbor.  We called my mom in New Hartford, NY and also called Father Tom Brown in Brazil for his birthday. Both were very excited to hear from us. Now the menu said: "Small Fish Fried", and not needing a Large "Fish Fry", we both ordered that, plus a salad and drink each.  Good thing we at least had those, because I could not even look at the bucket of tiny fried SARDINES!  Ed was good and had some and I just looked away at the scenery at the harbor.  But, I made up for this meal later. After Skyping with Emily and Margaret, we took the gondola (cable car) up to see the sunset on Mt. Srd. This was absolutely breathtaking! We did first walk through the Napoleonic Fort from which the men of Dubrovnik defended their city in 1991. There's a museum there and the video is quite alarming--especially when you see places we now know being bombed, like the churches in the Old Town and the Hilton Imperial where we were today. We ended on the roof watching the sunset beyond the islands, then caught it near the famous cross, and from the outdoor restaurant.  This is where I more than made up for the fish dinner with chocolate walnut cake and wine--actually, not bad together! Some photos below. wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Beautiful pictures! I love the night view over Dubrovnik! Can't wait to see you soon!

title: Saturday - 9/22/2012 - Medjugorje  Part I
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
We awoke early today and were at the car rental place by 8 AM.  Unfortunately, the person staffing it did not get there til after 8:15, but we were first to be waited on, so off we went in our Volkswagon UP!  A nice little car, standard shift, so luckily Ed was driving and not me.  Same side of the road as back at home, and we had a map, and Ed's prior experience going there, so we were OK.   Wonderful views of the Adriatic seaside towns!

We stopped once for coffee and had a very long stop at one of the three border crossings (we had brought our passports.) Medjugorje is in Bosnia, but the way the coastal region is divided up, you go in and out of Croatia and Bosnia a couple of times. All of this made us late for the 11 AM Mass at the church, but, thankfully, we made it for some of it.

Mass was held outside with today's perfect weather and it was beautiful.  There were hundreds of people from all over the world in the amphitheater  and about a dozen priests on the altar. It seemed to be all in Italian-the service and the singing.  At Eucharist time, they had everyone form lines down both sides of each of several aisles.  The priests then all came down and began distributing communion up and down the aisles. In spite of the numbers, it was very personal and moving.

After Mass, we went into the church to see the altar of Mary, which was also quite beautiful.  We then walked around the grounds to see the wonderful mosaics depicting events in the life of Jesus and the Stations of the Cross. We stopped for a short time at the famous Cross of the Risen Christ.   We decided to come back there later, as it was very busy. At that point I was not seeing the miracle of the "weeping Knee", but I did when I returned.

We had packed our own lunch so we went next to the picnic table area provided and ate there.  Every table seemed to have a group speaking a different language. We ate our peanut butter sandwiches, cheese, and oranges and drank our bottles of water (warm by now). We began our walk across town to the Hill of the Apparition. I'll write more about this tomorrow, as we came home renewed in spirit, but exhausted!

title: Sunday - 9/23/2012 - Medjugorje --Part II; Student, Faculty Picnic
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Back in Dubrovnik today, we attended a Mass in English at the Jesuit Church in Old Town.  The church (1620's) was damaged in the 1667 earthquake, and was rebuilt by 1725.  There are beautiful frescoes, several altars along the sides in addition to the main front one, and a grotto dedicated to St. Bernadette and Our Lady of Lourdes. I lit a candle there in memory of my sister, Marilyn, who took "Bernadette" as her Confirmation name. We had breakfast at an Irish pub-a great ham omelet, a few french fries, and toast. I took a short nap in early afternoon while Ed did some school work. We then walked to the East-West Beach for a picnic sponsored by his college student council. I got to meet a few of his students--they seem to have a good rapport--one invited us kayaking. I also got to meet several faculty members. They had cooked out hamburgers and sausages and had several kinds of drinks. It was a nice time. To continue about Medjugorje yesterday,  we walked through the town, past many little restaurants and gift shops to find the hill.  I had not brought my rosary from home, so I did pick up a pretty blue one to bring with me.  The MANY souvenir shops, especially right up to the base of the hill, are a little bothersome. On the other hand, when you come down, you do feel like you want to bring something home to share your experience with others. Anyway, if there is some commercialism about the town, you feel none of this on the climb up or at the top.  It is a rugged walk ,the path embedded with large rocks. People are quiet and prayerful, stopping occasionally to rest or pray at the depictions of the Joyful Mysteries of the Rosary. When you reach the spot of the 1981 apparitions, there is a beautiful white statue of Mary, surrounded by a small fence. The sight of this image, against the blue sky, overlooking the small town and  quiet countryside of grape vineyards, is something I will never forget. It is hard to explain how emotionally moving this was, but it seemed to bring every one of us to tears. The only sound was a small group saying the rosary and then softly singing "Amazing Grace", although I'm not sure what the language was. Ed and I picked a spot to the side for a while and said our own rosaries. He had one hand made by his Uncle Jack. We started down after about a half hour, past steady streams of silent climbers,  some very old, some quite young, many making the journey barefoot. When we returned to the church area, we went back to try to touch the Cross of the Risen Jesus. Ed had been up to it before and, because lines in the hot sun were long again, he waited on the benches. I waited for about 45 minutes and with the sun shining right on the knee area, the highest area you can reach, I could see that droplets of water did keep coming out of this metal cross!  Apparently, they've had metal experts examine this, and there is no scientific explanation for it.  I thought I would keep waiting until I could actually touch the droplets, but some people were staying there for extremely long periods, touching the water slowly and individually with dozens of small handkerchiefs. So, what had started as a beautiful spiritual moment was beginning to become annoying, and I stepped out of line because I did not feel that "annoyance" was a feeling I should be having at that time. And as I watched the sun gleam on the droplets, a thought came to me to question more not IF Jesus was crying, but what things in the world would make Him cry and the importance of seeing His tears in others.  Those thoughts have stayed with me, we feel we had a very blessed day,  and will treasure our time in Medjugorje. If you would like to see this for yourself  here  is a video someone else took on Youtube. title: Monday - 9/24/2012 - Breezy Day for Wash ;  Move to the right, please.
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
Today was a perfect "wash" day--breezy, mostly sunny, and about 75 degrees. I took advantage by doing 4 loads- which means 8 dryer loads, since you can only put in half at a time.  So I kept checking for things to hang outside.  There's limited space so as things dried and could be taken off the line, I put up a few more things, and threw some in the dryer.  All in all, I spent over 3 hours doing this, but I got a lot done.  While waiting in between, I have almost finished "A Tree Grows in Brooklyn".--great book if you've never read it.

Before Ed went to work this afternoon we tried to take a walk in the Old Town. Had he still been living near the harbor, he could have known the number of cruise ships in today and been forewarned about the crowds. We could barely get through the gates. ( made my mom's question last night even funnier: "Do you ever see any other tourists over there?")

We decided to go to a much less crowded place--a park behind Ed's college building.  Surprisingly, he had never been through it.  Very pretty vegetation, lots of shaded park benches, and a glorious view of the sea. Plus, no crowds to walk around or through.

I've found this very confusing here until Ed explained it today. When people are walking towards each other, we normally step to the right. If the people coming in the opposite direction do the same, everyone's OK. But some people here keep stepping to the left and we almost collide.  Ed said it depends on which side of the road they drive on in their home country.  Brits and Japanese go to the left.  Croations go to the right like we do.  Interesting!  So people aren't just being rude and stubborn.

We went out to eat tonight at one of Ed's favorites--Mimosa.  We both had delicious beef dinners, grilled vegetables, and potatoes. After dinner we walked to the other side of town to a large supermarket-similar to ours at home. The only thing we had to ask for help with was cream for my coffee. We  didn't know the word for it and I think the first thing we picked up was actually "sour cream", which would not have been good.

No photos today.  They would have just been of me hanging wash, bumping into people, or looking confused in the dairy aisle, so you're not missing anything.
