title: Tuesday - 9/25/2012 - Fun Swim Day-High Waves
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: You know what's weird about swimming alone--if the waves are really high, and you're having a ton of fun, bouncing up and down on them and getting thrown about--you can't yell, or laugh, or anything.  You would look crazy.  So you just have to keep your excitement in check and quietly enjoy the water. That was me today at the Banje Beach (EastWest). After a few cool days, it really warmed up again, and while my poor husband was teaching, I walked to the beach where Sunday's picnic had been held. The waves were wild.  You'd stand at the shore in ankle-deep water and get a wave up to your waist. Grown men were getting swept off their feet. It was great fun (both to watch and then go in). In the AM, Ed and I went exploring in Old Town to try to find a 1225 chapel we read about in a travel book. It survived the 1667 earthquake and is the only purely Romanesque building left in Dubrovnik. It originally housed the first Dominican monks to arrive here. We did find it, but not much of it can be seen because of newer buildings around it.  Apparently, it can be seen better from the wall, which we haven't walked yet this year. We had a wonderful dinner tonight at Ragusa 2, one of the restaurants on the narrow-upper side streets of Old Town. Ed had squid and I had fish fillet (no head, no bones, no sardines!). They came with a side of garlic potatoes and kale.  Delicious.  We walked around the town a little and out to the harbor.  The waves were still crashing along the rocks, and the moon, which is getting close to full, was lighting it all.  Some photos of the day and evening: [caption id="attachment_919" align="aligncenter" width="225"] The steps going up on our expedition to St. James church[/caption] [caption id="attachment_920" align="aligncenter" width="300"] St. James church (1225)[/caption] [caption id="attachment_924" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Banje beach, where Sue swam today. Note the canopied beds for rent (about $35). Sue laid her towel on the stones[/caption] [caption id="attachment_925" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Another view of Banje beach[/caption] [caption id="attachment_921" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Sue and Ed at dinner at Ragusa 2[/caption] [caption id="attachment_922" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The moon over the church of St. Blaise[/caption] [caption id="attachment_923" align="aligncenter" width="300"] The old harbor at night[/caption] [caption id="attachment_918" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Sue with one of the city guards at Pile gate[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Me too! I wish I was there to swim in the waves!
Loved your first paragraph!  I can just picture it :-)  Plus, I think that we ate at Ragusa 2 last year right?  Wish I was there! Miss you!
We certainly did eat there together.  I think it was a lot more crowded that night. Wish you were still here, too. Knew you guys would appreciate the swimming comments.  Love, Mom

title: Wednesday - 9/26/2012 - Plans for my last week
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: I've got to remember, somehow, that when I get on a bus, I need to be sure I am not facing backwards. I was so dizzy today by the time I reached Lapad, seeing everything go by in the windows backwards. Even the beautiful sea didn't look good that way. I was on a mission to make the first of 11 plans I've written down for my last week here--sort of a "Croatia Bucket List". We've decided that getting to Plitvice National Park is going off the list. As much as I'd like to see it, we'd have to drive all day Friday, then back all day on Sunday. Neither one of us really wanted to spend that long in a car. Plus I realized on last Saturday's drive that I don't do so well riding in standard shift cars or on winding mountain roads (and I was facing forwards then). So, plenty to do and see in Dubrovnik...! That's what took me to Lapad this AM. I was going back to a booth that advertised a "Three-Island Fish Picnic"--last year they approached me everyday about going on this, but we ran out of time. I think they were shocked that they didn't even have to try to sell me on it today-I know the hype by heart-I just walked up and booked it for Friday. I also swam at Lapad Beach for a little while. Missed the high waves, but got over my bus ride. I made dinner at home tonight. I know, it's about time. Ed had almost 2 hours between classes, so it worked out well again for him to come home. We had salad with cucumbers, apples, tomatoes,and his famous croutons. Main course was chicken, cooked with onions, red peppers, garlic in a light cream sauce (my coffee cream). Also had buttered carrots and grilled potatoes. Amazing what I can do when I have nothing else to do! In a little while we're going for a wine tasting. Can't wait to see what wine tastes like--Ha-ha! Just got back. The tasting was very nice. Along with the wine we got a meat and cheese platter. I can actually say that I've tasted wild boar now!! (in a pepperoni form, anyway) They explain all about the different wines, how they're grown from the same grapes that get varying amounts of sunshine. This one has a mild fruity taste, this one a wood flavored, this one more full-bodied and....blah, blah, blah...does anyone really care after that point? Did I mention it was good? Another edition of Travel So Fed. :)

Plitvice is amazing - might be worth considering driving from Zagreb sometime on a future visit, though, as it's only about 90 minutes from there.  Sometimes really cheap flights are available to Zagreb and it makes a fun weekend.

What about Kotor?  Have you been there?  Only an hour or so south, and definitely worth seeing on a day trip.

I know what you mean about riding backwards.  I suffer horribly from motion sickness and can't ride backwards.  And I had to drive everywhere because the motion of the car on those winding roods is so awful.  You have my sympathy!

The changing of the guard looks new!  How interesting.  They must have added it for the tourists?

Enjoy your last week!
We really are having a good time. Wish you were still here.

title: Thursday - 9/27/2012 - Kayaking, dinner at Sesame
dc:creator: epholden

title: Friday - 9/28/2012 - Fish Picnic, A three island tour
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Apparently, time isn't as big a deal over here. We were told to report for our "Three Island Fish Picnic Excursion" at 9:30 this AM.  We got there at 9:20 and the girl seemed shocked.  "Wow, you're early.  Come back around 9:45."  So we sat around for 25 minutes watching early AM swimmers, and then returned. After a few minutes, she began to walk us down to the harbor for our boat. A man came to meet her and said that instead of 10AM departure, it would be a little later. So close to 10:30 we took off. The boat was not that full, so we had our choice of seats. We chose ones right near the front, where we got the sea breeze, but also had a roof for shade. They immediately came around with plastic cups and poured some Rakija for everyone (liquor at 10:30 am). They also had boxes of wine that you could help yourself to all day-and some people did--we at least waited til late afternoon. It tasted just like you might expect wine out of a box served in a plastic cup to taste. These Croatians! Two things are very important to them--their faith (note the statue of Mary on our boat) and their wine (note the boxes right under the statue!) Our first stop was the island of Lopud. We had 2 1/2 hours here--supposed to be 3, but that time thing).  We went off exploring a 1483 church and monastery.  Before Columbus ever set out, this church was standing there!  Things like that amaze me. The monastery ended up being under repair and off-limits.  Right below this, however, was a great quiet swimming spot, which I took advantage of.  Hot day again. We stopped at a gelato shop (they're everywhere) and watched people at the main, sandy beach for a while.  Then we went up some pathways above the little town and took some photos. I'd love to make some into jigsaw puzzles.  They are that picturesque. When we came down, I swam again, this time in the main beach.The water is somewhere in the low 70's-very refreshing in the heat. Our fish picnics were awaiting us at 2PM when we returned to the boat. I actually cheated or" chickened" out, you might say, because that's what I ordered.  Can't get that bucket of sardine image out of my mind. Ed ordered the mackerel.  Both had a great wood-smoked flavor from the way they were cooked and were served with some delicious cole slaw         ( and wine, if you wanted it).  There were soft drinks and water, also. We started back out to sea while we were eating. Then we stopped for about 50 minutes each at two more islands:  Sipan and  Kolocep. We didn't swim at these, yet they both had nice beaches and little shops.  We walked around the cobbled back streets on both and found some interesting sites--mostly very old churches. A lot of richer families seemed to have their own private chapels.  We headed back around 5 PM.  Saw so many tour boats and even cruise ships.  Beautiful ride. So glad we went on this excursion! We ate supper about 6PM back on "Ed's harbor" on the upper outdoor patio of the Blindiinja Restaurant--four cheese pizza again-each restaurant's is different, and all good.  While there we watched the moon rise over Mount Srd (ahh..Kate Smith).  We should sleep well tonight! What a fish picnic![/caption] [caption id="attachment_960" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Sue took the safer choice - chicken[/caption] [caption id="attachment_961" align="aligncenter" width="225"] A statue of Mary holding the baby Jesus above two boxes of wine and other beverages[/caption] [caption id="attachment_950" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Ed on the way home. title: Saturday - 9/29/2012 - Hot day, night swim
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: For those of us my age or older, honking car horns on a late Saturday AM can mean only one thing--a wedding. If you thought road rage, you're too young.  Anyway, we heard this sound a couple of times during our breakfast this morning and it brought back memories.  Weddings here are getting very popular. In fact, several times during the week, I saw brides being photographed around the Old Town. I thought it was odd to see Tuesday or Wednesday weddings, but I think now they were just promotional photos.  But today's were real weddings and they rode through the streets afterwards.  Ed has seen them and said the lead car waves a huge Croatian flag dangerously out the window and everyone waves in celebration. Today was extremely hot, so we did not climb Mt. Srd as planned.  Possibly tomorrow .Ed had some school work to catch up on, so he went to the office for a while. Our apartment was cool inside, so I stayed in and made sauce. I doctored up a couple of jars we had bought with garlic, onions, parmesan cheese, and Ed's "mystery meat," chivaps.  We had  a nice salad and pasta with the sauce when Ed came in from the office. Later in the day we packed up to walk around Old Town.  Two goals:  to have coffee and dessert along the Stradum and swim in the moonlight afterwards. So we stopped at a little cafe and Ed had something like a custard with a light caramel sauce and I had something I had wanted to try all last year--"ice-cream pancake."  Just the name sounded like win-win to me.   It"s a gelato- filled crepe, and it was delicious, but a bit much.  Next time I need a dessert, it'll be just gelato. We walked over to Banje Beach afterwards, but it looked like they were setting up for a private party.  The tables on the beach were beautiful with flowers and lights that came from under each table.  Maybe another wedding.  We walked back to the harbor and I swam, where I really wanted to swim in the first place--off the Old Wall.  I pictured the same full moon over Pleasant Lake tonight, but doubted the temperature there would have allowed a swim.  Hearing fireworks now as we're getting ready for bed. ".   [caption id="attachment_970" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Wedding in Old Town[/caption] [caption id="attachment_966" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Nighttime at Banje beach[/caption] [caption id="attachment_967" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Sue swimming in the moon light[/caption] [caption id="attachment_968" align="aligncenter" width="225"] Full moon from the old wall[/caption] [caption id="attachment_969" align="aligncenter" width="300"] Waiting for the catch of the day[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I finally got back on the blog.  Have enjoyed looking at all the pictures.  Beautiful!  Like seeing Ed's apartment too.  Take care and safe trip home.

title: Sunday - 9/30/2012 - Conquering Mt. Srd
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today started out a little cooler and cloudier than the past few days, and it was our only choice left, so we picked it to climb Mt. Srd.  It was 77 degrees when we started out before 9 AM, stopping just for 2 bottles of water at the corner Konzum.  We made it up those 468 steps we had checked out a while ago, the just walked along the road about ¼ mile until we found the path and MORE steps. I don’t know if they don’t want people to go on this hike or what, because nothing tells you you’re headed the right way (except for Ed who had been there). Aside from the steps at the beginning, most of the trial is just a gradual uphill, stony, switchback trail. The beginning is shaded with trees, not unlike what we’re used to in the Adirondacks.  The top portion is pretty open and would have been terribly hot on a sunnier day. There are crosses along the route, numbered for the Stations of the Cross.  We paused and said a prayer at each one. Some have bomb fragments placed at the foot of the cross.  The Croatians are forever grateful for surviving the “91 War and saving the fort at the top. The closer we go to the top, the breezier it got, which felt wonderful.  We had fun picking out places we knew as we could see them—our apartment, Ed’s college, last year’s area, etc…  When we reached the top, we headed to the Panorama Restaurant to eat.  We had left without breakfast planning to reward ourselves at the top with a meal.  More than enough of a reward-you can see the photo that follow. As if there wasn’t enough cholesterol in those fries, they actually put a fried egg on their “club sandwich”! We probably should have walked down after that, but took the cable car. I’ve injured a toe and a knee since I’ve been here and downhill steps are the worst on them, so I gave myself a break.  We had a quiet afternoon-I actually napped and Ed listened to old radio shows on line.  A new discovery which I am quite sure I’m losing him to.  A friend (thanks, Therese) sent me an e-mail about a site to get any old radio program—original Superman, The Shadow, Burns and Allen…he may not even notice when I leave on Wednesday. We headed to the bar off the Old Wall just before sunset and got great seats to watch the show.  Stayed about 45 minutes.We did get to the Franciscan Church for Mass at 7 PM tonight and then had a little supper at the Kolisem Restaurant at the foot of the Jesuit steps. wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I don't know who is enjoying this blog the most..you guys..or us reading it??...(Probably you but..I am really enjoying seeing the various experiences you guys are having each day over there...the trips, the meals, swimming and more and especially the beautiful scenery!  I hope this is a going to be your best "bucket list" week that you've ever accomplished Sue!  Great photos and text...keep up the good work.  Rain forecast for 8 or the next 10 days here.  Wish I was with you!  Take care.

Hi John, Glad you are enjoying the blog. Sorry about the rain in Oswego. It hasn't started to rain here yet, but when it starts in the end of October it really rains. You can walk up a steep hill in 3 inches of running water. I will be back in Rochester by then, hopefully. Ed

title: Tuesday-10/02/2012-Packing up; Couple watching
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: You know how you always read or hear:- "Check us out at www. etc..." and you think, "Who ever has time for this stuff?" Well, I have over here! If you want to take a little virtual vacation with us, pretend you're staying at one of these places: The Rixos Liberatus Hotel in Dubrovnik, The Radisson BLU Resort, right outside Dubrovnik, or the Hotel Villas on the island we visited the other day, Kolocep, Croatia. Google them--very nice! My last full day. In spite of impending rain, I talked Ed into going swimming one more time and we checked out the cave. Water was choppy, but not too hard for a swim. We also had time to to stop on his way to work at the Sesame cafe for coffee. I'm packing up today. What was I thinking when I went shopping? You either have to come with lots of empty suitcase space or not buy anything. I keep telling myself that I'll be glad at Christmastime that I have all of this, but today, I'm not so sure. For our last night here I want to walk the Stradun. It's interesting to "people-watch" there. Ed was pointing out that the couples never seem to match. The woman is always wearing something very dressy, and the guy is totally casual. Now this may not make sense to him, but it makes perfect sense to me. It's my theory that women come on these trips always hoping to get to something really high class or formal. So she carefully packs some of her best clothes. The guy just packs some easy travel clothes, and leaves room (smart) for the European beers he'd like to bring home. Now, when it gets late in the trip and they haven't gone anywhere too fancy, the woman pulls out her "outfit" anyway, and she's wearing it, wherever. The guy notices and asks if this means he has to get dressed up,too. She tells him that he can just wear what he wants and he does--some old shorts and T-shirt she can't believe he even packed to go to Europe. And there they are, night after night, walking the Stradun. I'm really going to miss it here. I had unbelievably good weather to enjoy everything. In a sign of the times this AM, the little store near our entryway had switched their display of colorful sun hats to one item--a rain poncho. Time for Rochester... title: Wednesday - 10/3/2012 - Sad day - Sue left
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Last night, after our stroll on the Stradun, Sue and I were invited to our landlady's apartment for a drink. We had a nice conversation over a glass of wine. It was interesting to talk to someone who was born here but went to the US when she was 11, and now lives back here part time. She and her husband are travel agents back in California. She is staying for another week or so. This was a sad day. Sue left this morning. 8-( We have had a great time while she was here, as you have seen from her blog entries. I will miss her greatly. As of this writing she has left Dublin and is headed to JFK - the worst airport in the world. From JFK she will fly Jetblue to Rochester where Zac, my son-in-law, or Victor, my neighbor, will pick her up at about midnight. It is comforting to know that so many people are willing to help out. Be nice to Sue, she will be going through Dubrovnik withdrawal, which can be severe at times. This is a hard place to leave. It is also a sad day because now I am writing the blog again and you will have to read my writing 8-) After breakfast, we walked for a last trip to the garbage station, always a smelly event, then got one last gelato and a stop to watch the sea. Her Stracciatella (chocolate chip) had extra chocolate. She was happy. Marco, our driver, picked us up about 11:00 as arranged and we got to the airport at about 11:30 for her 12:30 flight. The Dubrovnik airport is actually in Cilipi. It is smaller than the Rochester airport and is easy to use, like the Rochester airport. It had a moment of disaster in 1996 when  U.S. Secretary of Commerce during the Clinton administration, Ron Brown, was killed in a plane crash in 1996, shortly after the homeland war ended. He was on a trade mission. There is a Wikipedia article about it here. The airport was not fully functional at the time and that combined with errors caused the crash. Today it is a bustling modern airport that sees over a million people per year arrive for a stay in Dubrovnik. On the way to the airport, Marco wanted to show me the remains of an old Yugoslav military installation that was a resort for top brass, when Yugoslavia existed. It was bombed heavily during the war and has never been repaired. The ride in through the palm trees on the disheveled and ravaged grounds gave you a glimpse of its former glory. The buildings were beautifully constructed but now bombed and riddled with bullets. There is also a beautiful beach. Marco stopped at one building with a caved in roof from a bomb and debris cascading down an elaborate main staircase. It must have been beautiful. Marco pointed out that the entire old city of Dubrovnik looked like this at the end of the war. Dubrovnik certainly has done an unbelievable job of restoration. There is a plan to refurbish this site also to accommodate more tourists.  This and the Belvedere Hotel, another unrestored hotel on a beautiful site, would make a good investment. There is interest by a local investor. There is an article here but plans have fallen through before. I wrote about the Belvedere in last year's blog (11/16/2011). After taking Sue to the airport, I returned home to get ready for class and office hours. My last class ends at 20:00. After class, my colleague Paul and a professor from RIT who is here for a conference are going to the cave bar that Sue discovered and wrote about at the Hotel More. The bar tender said he knows how to make a Manhattan (Hear that JOHN, a Manhattan!!). I will report on that tomorrow. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Thursday – 10/4/2012 – Back to reality - busy day
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, last night’s trip to the cave bar at Hotel More was fun, but no Manhattan (Hear that JOHN, no Manhattan). I guess I will have to wait until I am back in Rochester and Jerry can make me one at Mr. Dominic’s at the lake.  The trip was fun, though. Paul, my colleague from ACMT, and I took the bus to the Promenade in Lapad and met Zack from RIT, in town for a conference. On the way we met Doug and his wife Deb and we all went to the cave. This was becoming quite an expedition. Here is a picture of us having a drink. We had a nice time in conversation. As we were leaving at about 23:00 the place was just beginning to fill up. Croatians go out late. [caption id="attachment_1018" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The group in the cave at Hotel More[/caption] The reason I decided not to have a Manhattan was that the bar tender really did not know how to make one. I was going to show him, and he was willing, but he seemed uncomfortable because it was not on “the card” and he also had a limited selection of whiskey.  So no Manhattan is better than a bad Manhattan. I had a Somersby Cider instead and was happy with that. Cider (hard) is a popular drink here, but more so in the UK and Ireland. I got home about midnight and began following Sue’s trip on the internet. I got up a few times during the night to see how her flights were going. She arrived safely and almost on time. I had an email from her this morning and all was well. Thursday is one of my heaviest workdays and it was a difficult day. There were some technical problems again that I have just not figured out. We have not had these problems at RIT. I feel badly because it frustrates the students. I will try to work on it this weekend. About 13:30 Paul and I decided to walk down to the sandVich shop and get a chivap sandwich for 25 Kuna (about $4). They are big and after eating it I decided that I would probably not need dinner tonight. I was concerned because the shop was closed for the last couple days. It turns out that the lady who works there had been sick and there was no replacement. When I got out of work today at about 18:00 I decided to go to Mass at 19:00. Today is the feast of Sveti Franjo Asiški (Saint Francis of Assisi) and since I have been going to a Franciscan church, I though it was particularly appropriate to go to Mass today. It was not a unique idea. The bells rang as usual about at about 18:40 and when I got there at about 18:50, there was a special ceremony going on in front of the alter dedicated to Sveti Franjo (pronounced Frahn-yoh). The ceremony ended about five minutes before Mass started and seemed to involve men who were novices in the Franciscan order. The church was packed – standing room only. When Mass started there were eleven priests concelebrating. Although my Croatian is weak, I think they said that the principle celebrant was the Provincial. Here is a picture taken at the beginning of the homily. [caption id="attachment_1019" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Mass on the feast of St. Francis in the Franciscan Church[/caption] The Mass was beautiful. There was a choir in the choir loft accompanied by the organ, which I have not heard played before. It was a very moving ceremony and lifted my spirits after a difficult day. I brought my printout of the Mass in Croatian and I am getting pretty good at the responses. After Mass I left church and went to the candy store that Sue likes, to buy some of the fruity candies I like. I have been living with a woman who was a bad influence on me who will go unnamed (Sue) and she got me into candy and gelato. They were out of the fruit chews so I bought four chocolate covered cheries for 5 Kuna. I haven't eaten them yet, but I will have to stop going to that store. On my way back, I stopped for gelato at our favorite store. I was recognized as ACMT and the gelato was free. It is nice of them to do it. When I came out I ran into one of my students and had a long conversation with him. He is one of my favorite students and a joy to have in class. I think he will be very successful. We talked about a lot of different things and I asked if he would like a coffee or a beer, but he had to check on his grandmother. His mother is out of town and he was worried about his grandmother. I have no classes tomorrow. I have some meetings but I do not have to be there early. This is a long weekend here. Croatian Independence Day is Monday 10/8/2012. Holidays are celebrated on the day they occur and most have the day off. However, the following Saturday becomes the workday. I didn’t realize this about Monday because last year it fell on a Saturday, so it did not interrupt the class schedule. The students reminded me in class today. The same will be true on All Saints day, November 1. I just got off Skype with Sue. It was good the hear her voice. She survived the trip home, but is now tired. Well, that is all for now. Time to turn in. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Friday – 10/5/2012 – Busy but quiet day, two types of thrones, and The Adventures of Superman
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Last night I had planned to go to bed early, but for some reason, when I am alone, I get carried away doing things and the next thing I know it’s midnight. I have been obsessed with old radio shows for quite a while now (The Shadow, Johnny Dollar, Superman, …). WRVO, the Oswego NPR station, has them at 9:00PM every night. They are also on Sirius radio, which we have in our van. I love listening to them. While Sue was here, her friend Therese sent her a web site that has old time radio shows. That kept me up until midnight listening to The Adventures of Superman from the 1930’s. It was fun. This morning I did not have to get up early so I slept in until 9:00. When I got up it was 73F and sunny – an absolutely stunning morning. A light breeze, clear sky, calm sea, what more could you ask? It got up to 77F today. I spent the morning doing some house cleaning. After Sue left, most of my energies have been spent catching up on school work, so this morning I cleaned up a little, did dishes, took in some laundry from the line and visited the garbage station. It didn’t take long. Thrones number 1: In order to get to the garbage station you have to walk by two sets of public toilets. The one nearest my apartment has been converted to a pay toilet. It costs 2 Kuna to use it – about 35 cents. No one will use it. The other one, a little farther away, up the hill by my garbage station is free and was constantly busy until a few days ago. That one, however, is now undergoing construction. They have spent several days constructing a barrier around the construction site; something that should have taken a day (Croatian time at play here). So that public toilet is closed. There has been an intensely political argument here about public toilets.  That is because the local populace was so outraged by the charge that the city backed down in putting a charge on the older one close to the garbage station. Now that it is under construction and the people are suspicious that they are going to put a charge on it. We shall see. I had forgotten how amusing small town politics can be. We had similar issues when I was growing up in Fulton, NY. It beats talking about the issues we have to confront in the larger cities. The issue now for me, however, is that it is hard and dangerous to get to the garbage station. You have to cross a busy street where there is no cross walk, on a blind curve, and then cross again with no cross walk, then repeat the process in reverse to get back. We shall see how long this lasts. Maybe I should use another garbage station that is a little farther away. Thrones number 2: The HBO series, Game of Thrones, is partly filmed here in Dubrovnik and in surrounding areas. Last year this blog mentioned seeing the filming and talking to the actors. They arrived here again last week. They are storing their trucks and some props in the parking lot not far from my apartment, between the thrones mentioned in the last paragraphs. This picture shows what is there tonight. My apartment is in the background on the right. [caption id="attachment_1027" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Props used in Game of Thrones and the trucks used by the crew[/caption] After the cleanup and my expedition to the garbage station, I went in to the office about noon. I had several meetings. Any free time was used to do school work. I left for the long weekend a little after 17:00. I got a lot done today, but there will be more work tomorrow as I plan the next couple weeks of classes and exams. I made a nice dinner for the first time in a long time. When Sue was here we often went out or Sue would have dinner ready when I got home. That was nice. Tonight, I cooked some boiled potatoes, carrots and chivaps with peppers and onions. It was good. After dinner, I went to Mass then went for a stroll on the Stradun. It was a beautiful evening. There was a beautiful sunset as I left for Mass. The picture below shows the view of the sky between the attached fort (left) and the detached fort (upper right). [caption id="attachment_1026" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Beautiful sky between the forts[/caption] Sorry for the miscellaneous musings here, but that is all for now. I have to go listen to Superman. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Saturday - 10/6/2012 - Beautiful day to catch up, nice evening
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: The weather is so monotonous here - sunny and warm - just like Rochester 8-). It was a beautiful day today. It was about 68F when I got up this morning and it got into the high 70s during the day. I really didn't go out much until evening. I spent most of the day working and getting caught up. So it will be a short blog tonight. Not much happened until evening. While I was cleaning up from breakfast, I listened to another old time radio show. I mentioned them yesterday. I have been listening to the Adventures of Superman, but I thought I should vary my listening diet so I decided to listen to Yours Truly, Johnny Dollar. That is a series I enjoy listening to on Sirius radio when I am home and in the van. Each Superman episode runs about 12 minutes. Johnny Dollar, staring Dick Powell, runs about 30 minutes. I listened to the very first episode this morning from December 7, 1948. It was fun to listen to. This was the only episode staring Powell. Three other actors played Dollar from 1949 through 1962. I also compiled a grocery list so that I can go to the store tomorrow, just the normal things. So it should not take me long when I actually go. My friend TJ, who was here with me last year and was frequently referenced in last year's blog, came in for the weekend. He is stationed at ACMT in Zagreb this fall and is enjoying it there also. He is here staying with Paul and will be leaving on Monday. TJ, Paul, Sanja and I went out to dinner tonight at Nishta. Nishta is a vegetarian restaurant. Eddie and I ate there a couple of weeks ago. The food is very good. I had falafel and I enjoyed it. It was served on a bed of lettuce and cucumber on a pita with some hummus and some kind of red sauce that could have been ajar, my new favorite condiment. If you are interested in what falafel is here is a link to Wikipedia. It is like a fritter made of chickpeas. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Falafel Here is a picture of our group having dinner. You can still eat outside here. After dinner, we went to a bar called Exit. I had never been there before. It is upstairs on one of the side streets to the left of the Stradun. It was a nice place. We were there fairly early, but we decided to order a beer tower. It contained three liters of beer. That is a lot of beer as you can see from the picture below. The four of us worked on the tower for quite a while and we did manage to finish it. I looked around the bar for signs that they could make a Manhattan and I got optimistic so I asked the bartender. He said he could make one but he couldn't figure out how to charge for it because it was not on the price card. Bartenders here seem to be obsessed with that card. So, no Manhattan. At a little after 21:00 I decided that the old man had to go home. So I left the young people to have a good time. It was a very enjoyable evening. It was good to see TJ and good company all around. We will have to go to Mr. Dominic's when we get back to Rochester. When I got home, I called Sue to check in. Kelly answered the phone, which surprised me. Kelly and Justin came in for the weekend, as well as, Laura, Katie and the boys, Sammy and Jack. Cousin Amy also came with Katie to help her with the boys. Sammy said "Hi Papa" and went to the globe to see where I was. They had been to the apple farm earlier. They were all getting ready to go to Emily's house for Maggie's birthday. That is one of the things I miss about being over here. I then called Emily. She also has a house full of company from Zac's side of the family. I thought it best to call before the party started.  Maggie said "Hi Papa" and asked how I was. I can't wait to see her when I get home. Well that is all for now. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hi Ed, I read these every day and so enjoy them.  Sister Miriam
Thank you, Sister Miriam. I am glad you enjoy them. It definitely is a nice place here. Ed

title: Sunday - 10/7/2012 - Beautiful day, fun evening
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Well, so much for going to bed early. As I mentioned before, I have a tendency to putter around. Last night I had an email from a student who was having a problem with a homework assignment so I decided to answer so he would not be held up. Plus, I read the news and other things.  I went to bed at 00:30. So this morning I slept in until about 9:00. I had planned to get up a little early and go to the 9:30 Mass but I couldn’t make it. So I got up and after morning prayer, had breakfast, took yesterday’s laundry off the line, got ready and went to the 11:00 Mass. It was about 72F when I went to Mass and it may get up to 78F. It is cloudy today, however. When I got out to the street, I saw massive crowds and buses. I have not really seen this for a week or so. The tourist season is at an end, but today it seemed to be back in full force. To compound the problem, they must have been filming Game of Thrones in the early morning hours and the set crew was trying to remove lighting, set pieces and hay bales (some not so baled) from the Pile gate area while the tourists were trying to get in. The film crew security was having a difficult time making way for the crew. Similarly, tourists were trying to get out of the church as I was trying to get in. It made a problem of my commute to church and I arrived two minutes late. As I left church, I was filing out of the Pile gate with the tourists and decided I had better go in a different direction today. Out in a play area below the Pile gate, they were feeding the actors and crew. It smelled good. I wonder how I could act as an actor. Hmmmm! When I got to the street, there was the usual traffic jam of tourists, taxis and buses. One taxi was blowing its horn at a motorist who had parked in the taxi zone and it was Marco, my regular driver. The policija were heading toward the woman so she made a quick getaway. They do control traffic well here when the tourist flow is heavy, considering the tight space and volume. Marco pulled up to wait in line and got out to talk for a minute. He told me that there were five cruise ships in today. That is probably about 15,000 people. This will be a good day to get groceries. My favorite store is in the opposite direction. Marco wanted to know how Sue’s trip was and I said good and almost on time. His response was, “And you were worried about her!” When I got home, I answered a couple emails, one had a lengthy reply to a student. He had been working hard on a program and I think my response helped, so he said in a later email. I then walked down to the Tommy to get some groceries. It was a successful trip. I got another 6 liters of water and some other things I needed. I also got the makings for lentil soup. I am not sure when I am going to make it, but sometime soon. It was a nice day here and I decided to walk home from the store. Here is a picture of what the sea looked like about 14:00. [caption id="attachment_1040" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] The beautiful Adriatic sea. Note there are clouds in the sky[/caption] On my way home I met a young Korean girl who was looking for a beach, any beach. Now understand, looking for any beach in Dubrovnik is kind of like asking to be shown any leaf on a maple tree. There are beaches everywhere. She mentioned Lapad, but did not want to go that far when I pointed out where it was on the map. So given our location and that she did not care about what the beach was like (sandy, rocky, deep) I decided to take her to Dance beach behind ACMT.  I left her at the corner and pointed and described where to go so I am sure she found it. This was her last day in Dubrovnik. She had been here five days and was going to the Elephite Islands tomorrow then on to Zagreb for a couple days. She asked about beaches on the islands and I told her about the beaches on Lopud, where Sue and I went. After Zagreb she was then going back home to Korea. I told her about the technology museum in Zagreb. It is out of the normal tourist area so she may not find it. We had a nice conversation. After we parted, I went home to put groceries away. I then did some more school work preparing for next week. While I was working on school work, I listened to a couple of episodes of The Shadow from 1930 and a Yours Truly, Johnny Dollar from 1949. I love the old time radio web site. Tonight was a beautiful night. The temperature is pleasant. As I mentioned yesterday, my friend TJ is in town for the weekend. He is leaving tomorrow at about 5:00 AM. Marco is picking him up. Tonight we had dinner at Domino Steak House, one of my favorite places. We met at 20:00 at Domino. We were joined by Marco, the driver I have mentioned and talked to this morning and his girlfriend, Danielle. Danielle is a tour guide. We had a very nice time. After dinner we went to a bar called Skybar and had a beer. We had planned to go to the Irish pub, Graff, but it was too crowded. We were joined by a colleague, Kevin, from ACMT and Paul and Sanja. We had a nice time.Kevin and I left about 23:00. Kevin lives near the top of the hill above ACMT so we walked out together. When I left my apartment for dinner, I saw Marco’s car parked in a taxi zone across the street so I knew he was going to get there ahead of me.  Here is a picture of his car. [caption id="attachment_1041" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Marco's car[/caption] It is a Chevy Orlando, a model we do not have in the US. It is a nice car, a little smaller than a Chevy Equinox. His car burns natural gas and it saves him money since he puts so many kilometers on it. It also comes in, more common, diesel and petrol (gas) versions. It is expensive to drive here. A drivers license, renewed every four years, costs about 5,000 Kuna ($833). I guess I won't complain about NYS. There are also similarly high fees for car registration, but it includes insurance. When we had finished dinner, Marco asked if we were ready to leave, and we responded that we needed to get the bill. Marco had already paid the bill, that we were his guests. That was very nice of him, and unexpected. Thank you, Marco. Here is a picture of the group at Domino. [caption id="attachment_1042" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Friends TJ, Marco and Danielle with me at Domino[/caption] That is all for now. It is 00:05 and I am going to get ready for bed. I have to start getting to bed earlier. Fortunately tomorrow is a holiday (Croatian Independence Day).  Hope all is well. Ed

title: Monday – 10/8/2012 – Day off – Srd, Soup and Study
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Tragedy struck. Yesterday when I was getting groceries I accidentally bought Chocolate Crunchy Pillows instead of Vanilla. It is just not the same. So for the rest of the week, I will have to eat chocolate for breakfast. It is just not right. Those of you who have followed this blog for a long time know about my love affair with Crunchy Pillows, but it is only the vanilla that I like. The company that makes them is Dr. Oetker and they are called Vitalis Crunchy Pillows. As far as I know they are not available in the US. Oh well, I will have to persevere. What a beautiful day today was. I was glad to have the day off for Croatian Independence day. It was very windy overnight and this morning but it calmed down as we approached noon. It was 62F when I got up around 9:30 and got into the mid-70s. I decided I would climb Mt. Srd today and explore a bit to the left (NW) of the Napoleonic fort. The right (SE) side is where the cable car, restaurant and Cross are. I have never gone to the left. Last night, while I was mistakenly buying Chocolate Crunchy Pillows, I looked up from the Tommy grocery store parking lot and noticed that there was something that looked like another fort a ways to the left. So I decided to see what it was, if I could get there. Before leaving, I got the ingredients together for lentil soup. I bought those yesterday also. I put the lentils on to soak. They don’t have celery here like we do. They consider it animal food, but they do use celery leaves and celery root as a seasoning. They sell it in the produce section. They also sell a soup starter kit with a piece of celery root and leaves, a parsnip, four carrots and a cabbage leaf. So I bought one of those (3.99 Kuna). It takes about an hour and a half to climb Srd if you go at a comfortable pace. I have gone both faster and slower. I decided that I would buy a bottle of water on the way. Unfortunately, I forgot that all the stores outside the tourist area would be closed today. Oh well, I can have water at the top. Here is a picture of the view of the detached fort from the start of the mountain trail. It was a beautiful day. On the way up, near the top, they have been building some things that I think are going to be benches, though I am not sure. They had started when Sue and I climbed last week. They are building them out of stone. Here is a picture of one of them. Notice the stone chips at the base. They shape each stone on site. When I got to the top, I went into the restaurant to get some water. I decided to sit down and have a piece of chocolate walnut cake (sorry, Sue) and a large bottle of sparkling mineral water. Every hike should have this at the top. While wandering, I found what I was looking for, but it was not a fort. It was more like an old wall. I did, however, see some interesting things. Some farm animals that I knew were there, but had never seen. My friends Elizabeth and Stina had mentioned them last year. Stina had seen and confronted them while out running. There were also ground fortifications and foxholes leading to different places that, I think, must have been used during the Homeland War in 1991. Here are some pictures of what I found. [caption id="attachment_1053" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Farm animals, complete with cow bells. I wonder if they like the view.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_1054" align="aligncenter" width="1024"] Ground fortifications[/caption] [caption id="attachment_1055" align="aligncenter" width="768"] More ground fortifications[/caption] [caption id="attachment_1056" align="aligncenter" width="768"] Below ground foxholes leading from one fortification to another[/caption] I then went back down the mountain and returned to my apartment. On the way I found a nice outcropping of flowers that Sue and I like. Every time someone tells me what they are, they say it fast and it does not register. So I have no idea what they are called, but they are everywhere. Another plant that grows everywhere is lavender and it was really fragrant today. When I got back into civilization, I noticed that there was a huge traffic jam where the cars are trying to get back into the city. There is a loop road that goes around the city but it can become a single point of failure, as we would say in the IT business. A traffic jam seemed odd since it was a holiday, so I figured something was going on. As I walked further down, I found the cause. People park in these diagonal parking spaces then have to back out into traffic. Sometimes people refuse to stop. This is one of those cases. Moral of the story: when driving a Smart Car, don't confront other drivers. I couldn’t figure out why they just didn’t move the cars to get them out of the way and get traffic moving, and several people walked down to tell the girl in the yellow Smart Car to do just that, but she was not budging, until the policija arrived. The officer had a nice BMW motorcycle. Well, that was enough excitement for the afternoon, so I continued home to make my soup. As I arrived, Luci, my landlady, was sweeping up the grape leaves that fell in the wind last night. I mentioned that I was making soup and she gave me some nice bacon to flavor the soup. She had a lot that she had just bought. She also gave me some nice red sweet onions for a salad and some dried figs. When the soup was finished, I brought her a large bowl. I kilo of lentils makes a lot of soup. It came out pretty good, if I do say so myself. I also made some croutons to put on top. While the soup was cooking I took the garbage out and here is the view of the wall and one of the towers of the old city. Now I have some studies to prepare for class this week. Well, that is all for now. Hope all is well. Ed

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
The flowers are bougainvillea.  They are gorgeous!!

Glad you saw some of Stina's old friends from her running on Srd, and we are very jealous about the chocolate cake.

Love the photos!

Say "hi" to Luci for us!

Thank you for the flower's name. You may have told me before. Hopefully I will remember. The animals were interesting. There was actually a guy tending them yesterday. I had never seen them before. Ed
I forgot to mention that Luci says "hi". Ed

title: Tuesday – 10/9/2012 – Bougainvillea, bougainvillea, bougainvillea – I’ve got to remember that name
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded:
Well, thanks to Elizabeth, I now know the name of that flower I pictured in yesterday’s blog entry. It is bougainvillea. I think she may have actually told me this before but I am going to try harder to remember it this time – bougainvillea. When Sue reads this I am going to ask her to remember it also – bougainvillea.

It is a beautiful flower and seems to grow everywhere and it climbs whatever it is near. There are several varieties of this plant around the world, but the purple ones are prevalent here. If you are interested in this plant there is a Wikipedia article here.

We have had more mosquitoes this year than I remember from last year. The mosquitoes here are smaller and darker than in upstate NY. When I first moved in, in August, my landlord mentioned that they had been bad this year and showed me these electric devices that kill mosquitoes, but he hoped that they were mostly gone. These devices look like the electric air fresheners we have at home, about the size of a nightlight. So far I have not had to use them, but the mosquitoes are still out here.

They are small enough that when you swat at them, the breeze from your hand blows them out of the way. There are one or two mosquitoes in the apartment now and I hope they don’t find me.

Not much happened today. After breakfast I did some laundry and hung it out to dry. While that was in the washer, I did some grading and class preparation. My landlady stopped in to return the dish in which I had given her the soup yesterday. She said it was very good. It was a quiet morning. It was cool today, but sunny and breezy. In general, a nice day.

I went into school about 13:00 for office hours and Paul invited me to join him and his guests for dinner. His mother and a friend of hers arrived today from the US for a two week visit. After office hours I had class at 16:00. I gave an exam today. After the exam finished at 18:00, I went home to get ready for dinner. During class it started to rain so there was a light drizzle throughout the evening.

Before dinner, I wandered around the old harbor. There was a cart with a fish that someone had caught today. It looked like a tuna and was about five feet long. When I got to the end of the jetty, there was a beautiful cruise ship anchored just outside the harbor. It is a sailing ship and I think it may be the same one Sue saw when she was swimming one day. Here is a picture. Notice that they are just getting ready to lower the tender on the left side to bring people ashore. The tender arrived while we were eating.

Dinner was at the same restaurant where Sue and I had “small fish fried” a while back. I wasn’t sure about it, but that restaurant has been recommended. So I joined Paul, Sanja, his mother and friend for dinner and it was an enjoyable evening. Both the food and conversation were great. I ordered a platter that had octopus salad, salted anchovies, cheese prepared in oil and fish pate. It was very good, so I am glad I tried that restaurant again. Everyone else liked their food also.  We had a good time in spite of the light drizzle. After dinner we headed back toward home, stopping for gelato on the way. Sanja had to catch a bus back to Zagreb, about an eight hour ride.  She teaches at the University of Zagreb.

They have finished filming the Game of Thrones here for this year. The last of the filming was done near a restaurant that Sue and I wanted to try, but didn’t get the time. The restaurant also did not have good reviews. It is across the street from my apartment, down near the water. Here is a link to an article about the final day of filming.You may have seen pictures of this area in my blog before. It is below the detached fort that Eddie and I toured when he was here.

Well, that is about it for today. Hope all is well. Ed

title: Wednesday – 10/10/2012 – Busy day
dc:creator: epholden
content:encoded: Today was a very busy day. Wednesdays are days when I work at home in the morning, have office hours from 12:00 to 14:00, programming class from 14:00 to 16:00, a break from 16:00 to 18:00 and database class from 18:00 to 20:00. Then I go home. So there is not much interesting to report. It was a beautiful day again. Now, at 20:30, it is still 66F. It got up into the 70s today. It was really a nice day. Though I spent most of it inside, it was nice to have the windows open. Tomorrow, another busy day, it is supposed to be partly cloudy and 71F. Then we are to get some rain on Friday, Saturday and Sunday. This concerns me a little because we are going to the island of Korcula on Sunday. We will take a ferry to get there. I am the chaperone for the study abroad students. One thing about the weather here is that the prediction is often wrong. Let’s hope. Going out on the sea on a ferry to an island, in the rain does not sound inviting. We will see what happens. I came home on my break between classes and had some leftover lentil soup from Monday.  It was good. I have a lot left. Some is still in the refrigerator and I also froze some. I think I will have lentil soup for the rest of my life. It will be good to have when we start getting cooler days. One interesting thing that was reported today in the Dubrovnik Times was that the Hotel Imperial Hilton won the award for being the best hotel in Croatia. The hotel is next door to my apartment and is a beautiful place. You can stay there during the tourist season for about $500 per night. Needless to say I have never stayed there, but it is a nice hotel. It is gorgeous on the exterior and interior. I go occasionally to rent a car or for a meeting.  It is a 19th century hotel that was severely damaged in the Homeland War in 1991. I have seen videos of it burning. It has been restored to its former glory and is now a 5-star hotel. There have been pictures of this hotel on my blog before. Here is the article about the award and here is another with the history of the hotel. I hope you will find these interesting. It is interesting to think that when the hotel was built, Dubrovnik was part of Austria. That is all for today. I am off to do some grading and then to bed. Hope all is well. Ed
